Welcome to the Language Corner. Please take a moment to review these guidelines before you post.       
Switzerland has three main official languages (German, French, Italian). To make it easier for people to select the threads that interest them please prefix your subject line with the name of the language. For example:         
In some cases no prefix is necessary, for example:       
As always - try to make your subject line as relevant and as informative as possible.     
Discussions here should be limited to the use of language as it applies to life in Switzerland. This could include the use of English (see next section), but should not incude other languages (e.g. Spanish, Japanese) unless they are relevant to a topic in discussion (such as highlighting the difference between German and Japense, or the similarities between Italian and Spanish).        
This forum may be called "English Forum", but the focus is for English-speaking people living in Switzerland. This area  . Posts from non-natives (especially outside Switzerland) looking for help with their English  . There are other forums on the internet that deal with the English language, please use these instead (hint: google).   
From time to time there may be coverage about the English language but this will only be in the following cases:   
Please take note of the following linguistic terms that are frequently spelled incorrectly by native English speakers (since they will be used often in this area):     , not grammer.   , not pronounciation. Pronounce contains an   after the first  , pronunciation does not.

post: good idea, but i am in aargau

I took the exam without much preparation other than doing a couple of practice exams. I found the use of English parts easy, I practiced those parts that I struggled with most. The oral part was not difficult either, in preparation I watched some videos and looked at the examiner notes on those exams, which are all available online as examples. This really helped, as I knew what was expected. The essay was not hard, but you need to know how to write different types of essays, letters, etc, once you have the structure right, the rest is easy. There was one part in the reading that I found tricky, where you had to put text pieces into the right order. The text made sense to me in a few different ways. The other part I found rather difficult was the 2nd part of the listening exam, where you had a variety of of muliple choice answers. I kind of guessed at some of those answers, but since I aced the other part of the listening exam, it didn't matter so much. I ended up passing with an A Grade.

I must say I checked some of the small print in HBS and I didn't like some of their terms&conditions. For example once you pay for a certain course, you basically can't change your mind, postpone learning or get a refund. Not even if you get injured or seriously sick. I see they have made some changes to web pages, so the terms might have changed as well, but at that time they were pretty clear about that. I can understand their position, saying no to one student, because the class is filled up and then people just falling out. But still, it seems kind of unfair. Hi, 
   I just wanted to come back to this to share what I've learned.    
You get up to Fr. 5000 to spend on different courses but only with certain approved education institutions. The Fr. 5000 doesn't have to be spent on one course, you can re-apply multiple times until you reach the 5000 limit.    
You can also claim up to Fr. 2300 for loss of earnings where attendence of the course has meant you have had to take time off work.   
While I have mentioned a specific vendor applying for this training above I am sure that there are multiple different ones and please don't take my earlier posts of an endorsement of them.The specific term for this monetary grant that I have come acroos is "The collective bargaining agreement for temporary staff training".   
With the vendor I used I had to fill out an online form which included my personal details, AHV number, nationality, residence permit along with other information.   
I have attached a scan copy of a leaflet which I was provided which explains the process in a flow chart (mods please let me know if this counts as advertising and if so I will remove it).   
I was informed the application process to seek approval could take between 2-4 weeks.         
Thanks, 
TheIslandMan

post: Look up keen on your Thesaurus. For me hobbies would be at the end of your CV as additional info on your character, not on a motivational letter.

io = I (1st person singular)   
tu = you (2nd person singular)   
lui = he (3rd person plural, for men)   
lei = she (3rd person singular, for women)   
Lei (always capitalized) = you Â Used to address a person in a formal situation, regardless of their gender. It corresponds to the English pronoun you (2nd person singular), but it is a third-person singular pronoun in Italian. Example: lui Ã¨ = he is, lei Ã¨ = she is, Lei Ã¨ = you are (formal). There's no plural form of Lei, i.e. it is not possible to address a group of people formally in Italian.   
noi = we (1st person plural)   
voi = you (2nd person plural) Â Used to address a group of people, regardless of whether you know them or not. Previously also used as a synonym for Lei, but not anymore (except for the elderly, especially in the South).   
loro = they (3rd person plural)   
Hope it helps
And Duo Lingo too of course.

Hi there.  Having gone through this process of online tests years ago, my personal recommendation would be to go to the   end of what the tests indicate.     
I studied a bit at home before starting German classes, and got placed into too high a class.  I could not speak much, could not follow the class, had different vocabulary etc.  I gave up.  So when I came to Switzerland I deliberately started from the very beginning.  Then when I was comfortable with how the classes functioned, and my prior learning started to help, it was easy to leap a month and catch up with my "true" level.     
I cannot help with child care, but Migrosklubschule may have something.  I have been with them most of the way and they are flexible and responsive and I have loved the classes.  Good luck!

After reading many texts in English I can usually spot non-native written text. It is not just about spelling or grammar, but about style. But even then I cannot write in such a style myself.   
So, if you cannot afford a professional copywriter, then my advice is: google each sentence or pieces of it, find similar sentences, and copy them without changing much.

post: I can recommend Orsini on Heuwaage

Re. speaking - one of my milestones in becoming fluent in German used to be related to the second level of humour - when they'll get your jokes, because the reverse has happened much earlier. I am pleased to say I have passed it.  
Writing more complex texts in German is easier when you have an extensive vocabulary, but every grammatical rule that you somehow failed to integrate into the so complex mechanism of actually thinking in a foreign language is so evident (and embarrassing, depending on the circumstances).  
One thing is sure - learning German it's a lifetime process.

I am just coming to the end of the semi-intensive A1.1 course at Flying Teachers and thought it was quite good. I had next to no German before starting and can now hold basic conversations, which is exactly what the course prescribed. The only thing I really didn't like about it was the length of the classes - they're 2.5 hours long, which was a little tough after a full day of work and then commute from Basel to Zurich. I think I would have gotten a lot more out of them if the course had been conducted over a slightly longer period with, say, 1 or 1.5 hour classes (like the Migros Clubschule lessons for example).      
I think if you don't have to go from work then this wouldn't be a problem but I will be using a different school for A1.2 just for the shorter lessons.
is there big difference between TELC B1 and Goethe B1?

Nonsense.   
The OP was awarded 90% for speaking ability at B1 level, which means their grammar is pretty solid. It's inconceivable that the written part was so bad that they didn't get a single point. Even if German writing is relatively poor, someone regarded as highly competent for speaking will know enough about vocabulary, word order and grammar to muddle through with a low-scoring pass.   
There's clearly another explanation. If this isn't simply an admin error, the suggestion about not using the correct answer sheet sounds fairly plausible to me.
It wasn't a course - just a one hour written and oral exam to test my level of German.

post: Oops, that was me, if anyone is confused. Forgot to log out of BakerGrl's account.

To second (third?) other comments:   
Often the admin's job is to fill in where an executive lacks local language skills.   
For instance, in an officially English speaking company you may find that top management and highly skilled employees are often recruited from the anglosphere. As these key people likely do not have German, French, Italian, etc. it becomes even more important that the admins are fluent, written and spoken, in the local and frequently used languages. Often native level fluency is a basic requirement of the job even in company where English is the official language used.   
Obviously YMMV, but if you are set on a career in admin, set your language goals realistically.   
Good luck!

I discovered this recently and thought it's worth sharing: Hiking (or just strolling around the village) around Braunwald leads you through countless book exchange shelves full of, you know, the usual stuff that tends to reside on shelves like that (crime novels etc, but the occasional serendipitous find that is truly awesome). 99% of it is in German which is why I put this thread in the language corner.   
You're supposed to bring a book if you take one (a non-enforced rule but makes sense). Perfect if you're, for example, hesitant to buy stuff that might prove too difficult for your language skills; just bring it back and try again...   
...and oh yes I know there's libraries closer to where people tend to live. But this one gives you a reason to hike too - and you'll be reading a different book on the train back!

post:
All germanic languages have a kind of infinitive particle: 
DE: zu 
EN: to 
DK: at 
NO: Ã¥ 
NL: te 
etc.   
But each language describe this differently: 
English:   is part of the infinitive form as such. 
German:   is not part of the infinitive as the ending -en (-ern/-eln) is enough to note the infinitive form as opposed to conjugated forms. This   is only one way to link two verbs in the same clause.   
This means that you just have to learn the rules when   pups up and when not in German and stop comparing.
Yeah, basically B2 is the minimum for registration with the authorities in your profession, but you basically need C1 or higher to work or do an interview and get a job.

In your application dossier you should enclose copies of all your relevant certificates, those you achieved after the age of about 12 years old, including school reports. If you get an interview, take the originals with you.

The white part is called skirting board.   
The vertical wood on the wall is called panelling. More accurately, that style s tongue-and-groove panelling.   
The decorative edging wood on the floor is a frieze, as previously mentioned.   
Regards     
Ian

thread: Learning Deutsch and hearing Swiss German

post:
It varies by country, but Captain Greybeard is right. At one end you have Spain, where J is pretty much exactly as the ch in German  . On the other end, people from countries close to the Caribbean (such as Cuba, Puerto Rico and Venezuela) do pronounce it as an H; in fact this is a quick way to distinguish someone from those latitudes, and also a quick way to mock them.    
Chile is at neither end, but I would say we pronounce J more like in Spain than like in Cuba.   
Best regards.

Ha ! :-)  
This original post made me chuckle, reminding me that when I first arrived in CH (from a big city), during my first startled supermarket visits, with feeble German skills, I was subjected multiple and seemingly infinite parting salutations at the supermarket check out (just when I thought I'd made it out alive, she'd say yet another thing for me to decypher). At first it literally had me turning back to face the Verkauferin, asking "wie bitte", as she inevitably said just one more thing:      all in Swiss German of course 
...I have since become used to the embracing politeness of Dorf life. And that a slightly slow motion goodbye is expected and polite. This isn't the impersonal big city after all. I like it, it's home.

Just wanted to give an update. In the end I've went with Voxea and I must say I'm super happy with them. Progressed quite a bit in A2 course and teacher really put lots of effort into it, helped and explained as much as possible. The other students were great (Foreigners with different backgrounds) and they tried to get the most out of the lessons. 
If it would be cheaper, I like to continue there, but for now I'll go for online classes.

post:
There are certain avoidable mistakes (capitalization anywhere but with nouns/beginnings of sentences, mentioning things in CV which belong in the cover letter and vice versa, misspelling of names/job descriptions) which should definitely be done perfectly. Others aren't as important - but if one hands in a cover letter which isn't at least free of grammatical/spelling errors, there are simply too many other applicants nowadays who possibly have gone through the trouble to weed out grammatical/spelling errors and thus might get a better chance at a job. The cover letter/CV is the first and sometimes only impression one can give for a job and thus score a job interview (unless you call in advance and know how to build sentences and keep up a job-related discussion in a foreign language while under stress), so one should make as good a first impression as possible.   
I believe that an applicant has enough time to convince the future boss of their abilities/will to learn when in the job interview, why risk not even getting a chance to attend a job interview if you can avoid it by writing a very good cover letter/CV?
Yea I suppose I should have reiterated that in the post and added the author.  I blame Tuesdays...zapped all my brain power.

[QUOTE=JagWaugh;2442253]Ilona, for you, stop reading English NOW, only read German. Magazines, Newspapers, books. Try now to start translating your own professional stuff into German. Try to establish some contacts in the field you are planning on working in and ask them to send you some representative texts so you can get an idea of the level and style commonly used. The higher the level you read at the better your vocabulary is, and reading literature from the field will help you get to grips with the terminology.

Life in the Australian Army....   
Text of a letter from a kid from Eromanga to Mum and Dad. (For Those of    you not in the know, Eromanga is a small town, west of Quilpie in the    far south west of Queensland )   
Dear Mum & Dad,   
I am well. Hope youse are too. Tell me big brothers Doug and Phil that    the Army is better than workin' on the station - tell them to get in    bloody quick smart before the jobs are all gone! I wuz a bit slow in    settling down at first, because ya don't hafta get outta bed until 6am.    But I like sleeping in now, cuz all ya gotta do before brekky is make   ya  bed and shine ya boots and clean ya uniform. No bloody horses to  get   in, no calves to feed, no troughs to clean - nothin'!! Ya haz  gotta   shower though, but its not so bad, coz there's lotsa hot water  and even a   light to see what ya doing! 
At brekky ya get cereal, fruit and eggs but there's no kangaroo steaks    or goanna stew like wot Mum makes. You don't get fed again until noon    and by that time all the city boys are buggered because we've been on a    'route march' - geez its only just like walking to the windmill in  the   bullock paddock!! 
This one will kill me brothers Doug and Phil with laughter. I keep    getting medals for shootin' - dunno why. The bullseye is as big as a    bloody dingo's arse and it don't move and it's not firing back at ya    like the Johnsons did when our big scrubber bull got into their prize    cows before the Ekka last year! All ya gotta do is make yourself    comfortable and hit the target - it's a piece of piss!! You don't even    load your own cartridges, they comes in little boxes, and ya don't have    to steady yourself against the rollbar of the roo shooting truck when    you reload! 
Sometimes ya gotta wrestle with the city boys and I gotta be real    careful coz they break easy - it's not like fighting with Doug and Phil    and Jack and Boori and Steve and Muzza all at once like we do at home    after the muster. 
Turns out I'm not a bad boxer either and it looks like I'm the best the    platoon's got, and I've only been beaten by this one bloke from the    Engineers - he's 6 foot 5 and 15 stone and three pick handles across the    shoulders and as ya know I'm only 5 foot 7 and eight stone wringin'    wet, but I fought him till the other blokes carried me off to the    boozer.   
I can't complain about the Army - tell the boys to get in quick before word gets around how bloody good it is.   
Your loving daughter,   
Susan   
--------------------------------------------------------------------   :    Dear Ma and Pa:    
   I am well. Hope yÂall are too. Tell Brother Walt and Brother Elmer     the Marine Corps is easy and beats working for old man Minch by a     country mile. They really ought to join up quick before all the places     are filled. 
    I was restless at first because they make you stay in bed till     nearly 5:00 a.m., but I am getting so I like to sleepin in late. Tell     Walt and Elmer all you has to do before breakfast is smooth your cot  and    shine your boots and buckles. No hogs to slop, feed to pitch,  mash to    mix, wood to split, hay to layÂ practically nothing. Men gots  to  shave   but it is not so bad, theyÂve even got warm water. 
    Breakfast is strong on trimmings like fruit juice, cereal, eggs,     bacon, etc., but kind of weak on the pork chops, fried potatoes, salt     cured ham, steak, sausage, gravy and biscuits and other regular     breakfast foods, but tell Walt and Elmer you can always sit by some city     boys that live on coffee and doughnuts. Their food plus yours holds    you  till noon when you get fed again. ItÂs no wonder these city boys    canÂt  walk far. 
    Speakin of walkin; we go on Âroute marchesÂ which the Platoon     Sergeant says are long walks to toughen us up. If he thinks so, itÂs not     my place to tell him different. A Âroute marchÂ is about as far as  to    our mailbox at home. The countryside is nice but awfully flat. We   donÂt   climb hills or nothin. Them city guys get sore feet and we all   get to   ride back in trucks. The Sergeant is like a school teacher. He   nags us a   lot. The Captain is like the school board. Majors and   Colonels just   ride around and frown. They donÂt bother you none. 
    This next part will kill Walt and Elmer with laughing. I keep     getting medals for shooting! I donÂt know why. The bulls-eye is purt-ear     as big as a chipmunkÂs head and it donÂt move, and it ainÂt shooting     back at you like the Higgett boys do at home. All you got to do is  lie    there all comfortable and hit it. You donÂt even load your own     cartridges. They come in boxes. 
    Then we have what they call hand-to-hand combat training. You get     to wrestle with them city boys. I have to be real careful though, they     break real easy. It ainÂt like fighting with that ole bull at home.  IÂm    about the best they got in this except for that guy Jordan from  over  in   Silver Lake. I only beat him once. He joined up the same time  as  me,  but  IÂm only 5Â6â³ and 130 pounds, and heÂs 6Â8â³ and weighs  near  300  pounds  dry. 
    Be sure to tell Walt and Elmer to hurry and join before other fellers get onto this setup and come stampeding in.  
 Your loving daughter, 
 Gail

Looking forward~

I'm trying very hard to learn Swiss German, but currently what I speak sounds more like bad Hochdeutsch with a Swiss accent and some Swiss words thrown in and some lapses back to Norwegian when I get out of my comfort zone grammar and vocabulary wise.   
I remember when I moved to Norway in the late 90s. Foreigners were easily identified by their lack of dialect as they learned "normative" Norwegian at "immigrant school". Didn't really help integration. I learned Norwegian while living in a Norwegian family and going to school and thus went right to the local dialect. It really helped me "blend in" and feel at home where I lived, and even if people could hear that I was a foreignerm they usually commented positively on my use of dialect. Now mostly people from the place where I picked up my dialect can hear that I'm not from there, and even they don't alway get that I'm a foreigner.    
In an ideal world, I would both speak and write Hochdeutsch and speak Swiss German fluently. For now, my immediate goal is to speak passable Swiss German, write understandable High German and understand both more or less fluently.

post: I have two tutors on Skype for conversation practice - both of them I found on italki.com - all the attention is on you.   My dearest one costs me Â£18 an hour,  both tutors I have are really easy to talk to and the time flies!  My mistakes aren't pointed out whilst I am speaking so train of thought isn't lost and the mistakes are added to the chat bit so you can see later on where you went wrong.  You can choose what you want to talk about or what grammar points you need help with.  I think this works out better than a class situation.

I would consider it positive.   
If he had said, "I   sugar in my blood.", less so.   
If he had said, "I have s**t in my pants.", very bad.
There's this starting next week:

Stick with it... after a certain point it becomes a lot easier, and you don't even notice that you're reading German. When I arrived here I just stopped reading English for the first 3 years... after about 8months to a year I rarely if ever needed the dictionary.

I've finally finished editing the audio and text for the 1961 film 'Frau Holle' (see the share link in the top post of this thread).   
The audio is 31 mins of continuous dialogue (no gaps longer than 1 second). 
The folder also contains a document with all dialogues. 
Note: i did not translate the German to English, I downloaded the subtitles direct from    
In addition, I've discovered an excellent lyrics plugin for Foobar 2000 called [Lyric Show Panel 3] which shows the words as you listen, see demo video here which has sound:   
Each MP3 contains the actual dialogues, and because I've setup timings for each line, Foobar automatically shows the words in karaoke style.

High German (better: Standardsprache, Standarddeutsch) is an artificial language for all German speakers. It was put together of all the dialects spoken to create a written language common to the German speakers of Belgien, Elsass, Luxemburg, Liechtenstein, SÃ¼dtirol, Lothringen, Switzerland, Austria and Germany. High German allows many local variants. It is like britified, aussified, scottified, eirefied and 'mericafied English as the thread opener so aptly put it :-)    
So die Butter and der Butter are both correct as der Tunnel and das Tunnel, Finken and Pantoffeln, Patschen and Hausschuhe are all perfectly good Standardsprache and can be used by any German speaker if he likes it. But Finken will be used mainly by the Swiss, Patschen by the Austrians, Hausschuhe and Pantoffeln mostly by the Germans. Trottoir and Gehsteig and BÃ¼rgersteig are all perfectly good Standarddeutsch and so on. 
Just because a German speaker from the northern shores thinks Trottoir for BÃ¼rgersteig is weird, it is nonetheless absolutely correct. As I once tried to find Rahm in a Hildesheim Supermarket, nobody knew what I meant and I tried to explain and then they found out...oh, you mean Schlagsahne! I certainly knew the word, but I normally use the more southern German Rahm which they don't use up there and it just didn't come to my mind at that moment, it was very funny after all!  There is no lesser or better German, there are just many valid variants.    
Dialects are something else alltogether, because they are oral and only written in informal situations. Sometimes this becomes kinda quirky: My niece speaks the same dialect as my sister and I at home. But when she writes me a text- message, she writes it in the local dialect; the dialect she speaks with her friends (BÃ¼ndnerland). Just love it.

Make sure you get a translator with some cultural understanding of the target market, if your website is targeted at the German/Swiss market. Translation prices might be higher but you should invest into a native speaker with some cultural knowledge- I have seen horrendous German translations on webpages!!!

Hi    
I've been meaning to post something about my experiences with passing the C2 exam for a while, so this is a good prompt.  My language journey is maybe a bit unusual, I brushed up an old German GCSE before I moved to Switzerland and managed to pass the B1 course before I made the move but once here I didn't have a strong desire to do a further course for about another 6 years! What prompted me to study further was a realization that when I had stagnated a bit and was making the same old mistakes.  I was also weighing up some further education (retraining as a teacher) and that also required the C2.  In the end I decided to plump for a private lesson (1.5hours per week at Sprachwelten in Zurich) and it took about 12 months before I felt ready to have a stab at the exam.  As with all language exams it's pretty formulaic so you really need to have the exam technique nailed, particularly as certain parts of the exam are pretty tight time wise.  You also really need to have the broad range of vocab and doing a course forces you to think about using alternative adjectives and phrases (rather than your stock ones).   
So what has the C2 brought me?  I think it's been a bit of a confidence boost to be honest because it was challenging and I managed to come through it.  It has also been a platform to explore new career opportunities (as I'd been working primarily in English).  Ultimately, having the goal of the exam also helped focus my learning on areas of weakness (for mewritten German and Grammar).    
Anyway best of luck if you do decide to go for it.

post:
For the days I completely agree with your interpretation as this is what I would use.   
For the months however I use 'this' for months in the current year ( irrespective of if it's in the past or the future) and 'last' or 'next' for the previous or following years.   
For example I would say 'this February' for February 2015 and 'last February' for February 2014 and 'next February' for February 2016. 
The same would apply for August so 'this August' would be August 2015 and next August would be 2016.
This test book is quite good ........

Whilst there's nothing better than talking with a german-speaker who can guide and correct you, you should not be inhibited from writing simply because your grammar is not perfect.   
The free online grammar checker of Duden will identify your simple errors. The only problem is that it does not give you the answers but if you have at least a basic understanding of the grammar, you can correct the errors that it pinpoints by trial and error.

post: Yup, crosswords and   Reminds me of this old joke (I feel entitled to go off-topic since the OP's problem has been solved):        One day, a shy gentleman was preparing to board a plane when he heard that the Pope was on the same flight.      "This is exciting," thought the gentleman. "I've always been a big fan of the Pope. Perhaps I'll be able to see him in person."     Suddenly, the man realized his seat was right next to the Pope himself.     Still, the gentleman was too shy to speak to the Pope.     Shortly after take-off, the Pope took a crossword puzzle out off his bag and began working on it.     This is fantastic, thought the gentleman. I'm really good at crosswords. Perhaps if the Pope gets stuck, he'll ask me for assistance.     After a while, the Pope turned to the man and said, "Excuse me, but do you know a four letter word referring to a woman that ends in 'unt'?     The man was in shock. He could only think of one word that fit the description and he was not about to say it to the Pope. The gentleman thought for a while longer, then it hit him.      Turning to the pope, the gentleman said, "I think you're looking for the word 'aunt'."     "Of course," said the Pope. "Do you have an eraser?"

I am the first to say that anecdotal, non-scientific evidence has limited value. But I have a certain amount of experience and observation and have lived in many countries, usually among Americans, and we sent all our children to local French schools at least to age 12. They all speak French, one is married to a French man. The children of the others all go to French lycÃ©es or (in 1 case) a French nursery school. I speak only French to him, others speak mostly English to him; he doesn't speak at all yet (he's not yet 2) except for a few words, arbitrarily one language or the other: un, deux, shoe, car. (FWIW all the grandchildren other than the French ones are Swiss citizens, so their parents agree that they ought to speak at least 1 Swiss language. Especially my son who went to college with a Danish guy who spoke no Danish, only German, because his German mother divorced his Danish father when he was a toddler and both Denmark and Germany bar or limit dual nationality.)   
I knew parents who sent their children to French schools and, one year later, despaired that they were learning nothing and took them out of the French system. Big mistake. Our kids started speaking French almost the first day of their second year of primary school, not before.   
Ne vous en faites pas : votre enfant sait plus que vous ne le pensez.    
There are books and books written on this. I started a thread the other day because I am interested -- out of curiosity not necessity -- in the learning of sign languages ( Swiss SL is based on the French system, as is ASL; British SL and German SL are different. Swiss German is close to Swiss French ). Anyway my point is that languages are easily learned before puberty, but not afterwards unless you have special aptitude. And while they are best learned beginning at age 0, anything before 5 is fine.    
Many years ago my daughter was in a class in Ecolint, French Section, Geneva. One of her classmates was a Down child with a high level of ability. He spoke 3 languages.    
Those are all anecdotes and should be read as such. I ask only that you take with some cynicism those who say that one should first be grounded in a single language before learning others. Whole generations of deaf children who were refused ASL because of the Second International Congress on Education of the Deaf (Milan Conference of 1880) where that view was established, were cheated: many never learned any language at all.    
Look around you in Switzerland: I had a Swiss ancestor who, on stage, told jokes in six languages. In the 1920s Iowa and Nebraska tried to make it illegal to teach a foreign language to a child. Happily the Supreme Court threw that one out: Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390 (1923); Bartels v. Iowa, 262 U.S. 404 (1923). (Gov. Ma Ferguson is reputed to have said "If the King's English was good enough for Jesus Christ, it's good enough for the children of Texas!" She didn't of course, but you get the point.   )   
Good luck. Hope that helps.

Hello.   
I've been pointed by others I asked (outside this forum) to Web sites that more or less answer the question. There are 10,000 deaf signers in all of Switzerland, 5,500 using Swiss-German, 1,700 Swiss-French, 300 Swiss-Italian and the others can be presumed to be using ASL.        
But: Wikipedia says "In 2011 it was estimated that 7,500 deaf and 13,000 hearing people use DSGS."   
There are also hearing-capable signers, some of whom will be trained as interpreters. Wikipedia suggests they number 13,000 in all of Switzerland.   
A general study for the Council of Europe is here and is widely quoted and distributed on the Internet:     
Wikipedia's English-language page on German Sign Language says: "It (GSL) is not related to Austrian Sign Language, which is used in parts of southern Germany, nor to Swiss Sign Language, both of which are part of the French Sign Language family, though they have had some influence from German Sign Language."   
Thanks to anyone who gave thought to my question. For the rest I shall have to get in touch with professionals in the field. I find it interesting that Swiss-German SL is distinct from the signing used in Germany, and that even in Germany there are distinct variants.

post:
I think reading is one of the best things she can do, and Antolin is great as it gives both of you a good idea of how much she is understanding. When you enter the name of a book it tells you the grade level but I wouldn't worry about that too much. I think any reading is good reading at this stage. We used Antolin a lot when my daughter was in the 2nd class (she's now in the 4th) and it really helped to build her confidence.   
You could also try the LÃ¼k and MinilÃ¼k puzzle as well ( )   
You can buy the actual puzzle device and also do it as an app, I think. There are lots of different puzzle books covering all aspects of German language as well as maths etc, and you should be able to find one specifically for the cases or that at least includes it. It can be expensive but try second-hand, too, such as Ricardo. My daughter's class also used this quite often in the 2nd class, I think, so ask your daughter's teacher if she can find some for you.   
Otherwise, my daughter's teacher gave her a book to help her understand the different articles, and therefore by default the different cases, too. It was from the Kantonaler Lehrmittelverlag St Gallen ( ) so that might be useful, too.   
There's also a ZÃ¼rich one ( ) and my daughter has used this online for maths, and I'm assuming it might have some good language stuff as well.   
You could also try something like Duolingo:   and I'm sure there must be lots of other apps out there.   
Good luck!

Hey Dan,   
I moved to Lugano 3 months ago from London. I have studied at the ILI school near the station for the last 2 months and was really unimpressed so I am also looking to change! As you have found out it is REALLY difficult online.    
I have been recommended the Migros language school in the centre but I am yet to try it out.   
What I would say about ILI is they only seem to care about the money you are paying. They gave me my start date and put me in a class much, much higher than my level (which they tested when I started!). When i complained they argued back that this was my level - trust me it wasn't. I can speak a little and understand practically nothing and this was a class that had been studying for 5 months full time! It was a constant struggle and when I was finally put in my correct level the class was 14 when they promise a maximum of 10. Half the people don't pay as it is where they send the unemployed so you end up being with people who don't care, try and waste alot of time.   
For an intensive course you will be looking at around 1000 - 1200 francs a month which (I think) is around 700 - 800 pounds. This doesn't include accomodation or anything but I do know some of the schools do this.   
I will try and keep you posted on what I find out as hopefully it will be easier for me being here.   
GOOD LUCK!!!   
Katie

post:
Nice translation UM. 
Yes it is quite beautiful.

Not wrong as such, but there's a huge amount of correct English that never gets taught. Accents are an entirely different kettle of fish. For example_   
Gasmask. The first syllable is usually pronounced with a short "a", but seldom, if ever, as "ar". The second syllable may be short "a" or "ar". The educated southern English pronunciation would be:   
Gas marsk.   
Of course, American English gives you gaas maask.

Have you tried this thread?     
lots of useful information on schools in Zurich

I would not recommend Migros Klubschule. I am aware they are very cheap, but my wife made a course with them (German for beginners) and her experience was not good. The classes were really slow and mostly they were losing their time doing silly games. If I would be you (I also studied at ETH) I would take one of the courses at the University of Zurich and study a lot by my own (this is key when learning a language).    
Also, I recommend you to do Tandem-Learning. The University of Zurich offers the possibility to register in a pool of people looking to do tandem and when they find a match they will contact you. Here is the  . I did it as a student and helped me a lot! Good luck!

post:
It seems to me that in spoken French most people don't care. It's certainly classy to get it right, but it's not a disaster to use the indicative. Similarly, as someone mentioned, saying "je sais pas" without the "ne" is very frequent and not a big mistake, but it is not classy - I never do it  .   
I read an email this week which included "il faut que j'est...". Oh dear, it should be the subjunctive of avoir : "aies" (or is it "aie"? wtf). The (French) writer knew that the subjunctive was needed, but didn't know how to spell it... Moral of the story: Foreigner learners - don't sweat what doesn't really matter!

Hi iboocheeky,   
If you have a smartphone, the easiest thing is to use the CFF or TL apps . Just insert the address (Rue de Geneve 60) and it'll tell you how to get there. The thing is, if you use the exact address it might not find very frequent combinations.   
Another strategy is to go to one of the main stops close by like Flon, Chauderon, or Vigie. These all have more frequent combinations and you can just walk from there.   
In your case, I think 66 stops at St Francois, right? If so, from St Francois you can just take bus 17 until stop recordon or boston (I'm not sure which stop is closest) and walk 5 min.   
Hope this helps,   
Dan

post: A surprisingly accurate explanation! Are you a linguist? I especially liked these two sentences because they are best describing what it is about with our language:      There is a little objection, however: Instead of saying Swiss German, you should use the lingustically correct expression Alemannic. That's the language spoken in the (French) Alsace, in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg, some regions of Bavaria (Germany), Vorarlberg (Austria), in the Southern part of Liechtenstein - and Switzerland. Using this expression would avoid plenty of misunderstandings. But I know, the Swiss will come up soon and oppose. They think Alemannic is only spoken in (Southern) Germany - and no Swiss wants to be confused with a German. Another old story...

post:
Hello all,   
Thought I would share a website with all which lists out all the facilities in Baden for German language learning...       
A few comments on whats on the list:     - heavily depends on the teacher you get stuck with... (therefore a lot of mixed reviews from this institute      - slightly cheaper option but again... right from the very start the tutor may only speak German. So if you don't know a word of German... better get starting practice from elsewhere and then go here.       - Good place to    because at the beginning they are slow, take their time and get repetitive in teaching you... so it may seems dragged out if are comfortable with A1-A2. However if you just want to learn conversational German (skip the professional certificates and grammar) I would highly recommend -  A friend managed to cover got from A1 to B2 in 2 years.      - personally I don't know many that have been here.. so if anyone has had any experience with these institutes feel free to share .. i would really like to know their reviews.

I was in your situation when I first came here so can comment from that perspective and also teach English so can comment from a teacher perspective. I signed up for private lessons as I needed the flexibility to have the lessons when I was here so I didn't miss any steps in the learning. 10 lessons were around 900chf and this would last me for between 20 and 30 weeks as I couldn't always go every week. My progress was slow but there was progress over the couple of years I had that set up.    
If you join a class and then can't go to some if the classes the teacher won't spend the time getting you up to speed as it wastes time for everyone that was at all the classes. You then end up with gaps of what has been covered and have to guess the in between info. It's also a waste of money.    
The language school where I teach has an online course called E-Learning through Rosetta Stone. It's not perfect but can be ok for people who are prepared to get on with it themselves and don't need a teacher spelling it out the whole time. It's also less expensive.    
I don't rate duolingo as anything other than a fun app. It has a lot of mistakes in terms of the meanings from German to English as doesn't provide any explanations. I suggest it to my students as a fun way of practicing in their free time but not as their only learning method.

It feels like it but strictly linguistically speaking, it isn't. I must admit that you might remember ZÃ¼ridÃ¼Ã¼tsch with less High-German "infuse" than the usual talk one hears in real life. But it's more a question of life style: Modern life is linguistically expressed in High-German adapted to dialect grammar and phonetics. The farther one is from modern life style, the more distant from ZÃ¼ridÃ¼Ã¼tsch a given dialect seems to be. It's just due to what one talks about, not the dialect in itself.  
Fact is Walliser is strange and will remain so for a while.

I just had a trial lesson with Easy Languages and thought it was worth a sharing. I can't find anywhere that they have been mentioned before or anything recent about online lessons - but apologies if I have missed something.     
I studied to end of A2 with Allegra in Zurich but haven't been able to commit to more classes as I travel a lot and am away usually at least 1 week every month.  
I also don't get much practice so what I did learn has not been put to use.    
A friend suggested these guys and so I gave them a try and so far I am impressed. They are under 100Euro for 5 x 1 hour lessons. You pay by credit card online and can chooses your lesson times. They seem to be quite flexible in that you can switch teachers easily if you aren't happy and as long as you cancel in advance you don't loose the lessons.  
I have just signed up for 10 lessons and will take it from there. I am concentrating on conversation German, and they are going to email me a text that we will discuss in the lesson,  but you can also work from text books and towards tests.

I'm in a perennial state of trying to learn German -- not with great success, admittedly. I like podcasts, and thought I'd drop in to mention the most recent one I've found that seems particularly useful. I have no relationship of any sort with these people, apart from being a subscriber.   
It's called Dazpod ( ). There is a free version that gives you a weekly podcast featuring a brief sketch, followed by some explanation. Typically, an episode lasts 15-20 minutes. All of this is in German, so note that the standard is not for complete beginners. They divide the material into Beginners and Intermediate level, but in reality you need to be at least A2.    
You can also upgrade to a paid version for 3 euros a month. For this, you get the podcasts plus a full transcript of each episode. Personally, I find this essential to enable me to look up words. But the cost is very low, so no complaints.   
What i like most about this one is the professionalism of the material. The couple acting out the sketches sound like pro actors, or certainly experienced teachers. And there is also a lot of humour and insights into German culture. I repeat - the material consists mainly of little playlets, which may not satisfy everyone. There are no long explanations about the finer points of grammar. It focuses on increasing vocabulary, understanding usage, and above all, listening practice.   
My only minor grumble so far is that there is no comprehensive   provided, so it means a lot of looking up. But for 3 euros, you can't have it all.   
Well worth a try.

if you are going into Finance, learn French.  yes, the German-speaking part of Switzerland has a banking sector, but it is inbred, strongly caters to local hires and is much more private-banking as opposed to pure finance focused.  and the finance markets in Germany and Austria (where your German would also help) are not particularly attractive, and will pay far less than elsewhere in Europe.   
with French, you will have the financial markets in the French-speaking part of Switzerland open to you, as well as the finance markets in France (Paris) and Luxembourg (which also trends toward private banking but is much stronger in private equity and other pure finance markets).   
lastly, the French language instruction at a US university will be tenfold better than the German language instruction.       
P.S. in the interest of full disclosure, I learned German and Swiss German, but I'm a lawyer and the legal markets are completely different than the finance markets.  in my experience, lawyers and engineers in central Europe speak German, and people in finance (again, leaving aside private banking) speak French.

post:
This just won't work because of the language + cultural requirements- eg an Au Pair goes to a country to be immersed in the local language, culture, etc, and follow a language course. Also they cannot have sole charge of young children- and can't work for more than 30 hrs, 50% of which with one of the parents present (part of the immersion requirement and for safety reasons).   
An Au Pair cannot be employed to teach her own language to the children - as that would totally defeat the object. When we employed Au Pairs in the UK, we had to speak English only at home (even though 2 of the Au Pairs were from French speaking Switzerland, like me).

I did an intensive course for 3 weeks at Innsbruck university when I first arrived.    
It is direct on the train from here, and a gorgeous city. It is not hard to find accommodation, as there are either hostels, or you check out the university notice boards for sub-leases as it is summer holidays.    
They also have activities organised daily in the afternoons.

I'm a Duolingo fan for sure.  I use both the app on my iPad and the website on my PC. They are slightly different.  When I'm doing a new lesson I try to use the computer because it offers more explanation, conjugations, discussion with other people, etc. I tend to use my app more for strengthening skills and challenging others to a competition for speed practice. I also like it because when you go back and strengthen skills they are usually more difficult than they originally were, incorporating new words or grammatical problems.    
I've been using it since January and I can tell a huge difference in my ability!   
For beginners, I really liked Michael Thomas's 8 hour program. Within a few days I felt comfortable enough to at least open my mouth and try to speak the language.  He also explained relationships among words and sounds that has really helped. (Unfortunately, not a free app.)   
I also have iLang, Lingo Arcade and Kleine Grammatik apps for very basic vocabulary and really great charts.    
Finally, my husband has been reading stuff on FB from "German Language Learners (Wir lernen Deutsch)" and I'm going to start looking at that also.   
Nur meine zwei Rappan!

There also is an other exam that you might want to take in consideration:   
it is the "TCF" = test de connaissance de franÃ§ais   
This one is cheaper, and you can not fail, because it's more like an evaluation test. However, it is just a comprehension test. 
You are given grammar, reading and listening score.   
E.G. you might be C1 in reading, but, say, B2 in listening.   
Good luck

OH has no sense of orientation- but I instinctively know where North/South/E/W are. My brother and I were trained very young. Dad yould take us mushroom hunting and tell us, you go this way and I'll go the other- meet you at such and such a place in 30 mins, etc. Perhaps he was trying to lose us, bless him, but he never managed. I learned both, more or less at the same time although the opportunities for speaking Swiss German in ZÃ¼rich far exceeded the opportunities for speaking German.  an A2 to B1 level understanding of standard German was very, very helpful for me in navigating Swiss German, but you can always learn the basics of both at the same time.  learning both meant that my standard German suffered (and still suffers, especially when speaking), which is a downside when trying to speak German outside of Switzerland or with German friends and colleagues.   
I have never had anyone switch to English when I speak dialect with them (Germans simply respond in German), when I try in standard German it is more of a mix.  I have also never had anyone react with anything other than surprise and a smile at my learning and speaking dialect, other than German friends and colleagues who cannot imagine why I would bother.   
good luck whichever path you choose, German is a harsh mistress but learning the language can also be fun.

Gypserie is another word that doesn't translate in "proper" French.  Something to do with painting and paints I guess as it's often alongside peinture on business signs.   
Paillard is French French though; it means lecherous or bawdy.

Hope you do find the light at the end of this horrible Tunnel. Summer is on its way and it will be much easier- walking along the beach, sitting out in CafÃ©s. What do you enjoy doing? Have you been out to discover some of the wonderful sights around Colombier, both by the lake, in town (s) and the mountains nearby? I know the rubbish weather these last few days are not helping- but Summer is defo on the way- s don't despair, honest.   
miniMia- yes a shame that so many teachers still have that mentality of teaching stuff which even educated natives would not have a clue about - not just in Switzerland either- very much the French way too, perhaps more so as this is the way teachers are trained and promoted (eg on sophisticated Grammar and Literature and not on the ability to communicate or teach). Although at C1 level, it does make sense to begin to tackle more complicated structures- as long as it is not 'just to trip people up' but to genuinely increase their communicative level. More appropriate at C2 imho. But it is totally inappropriate with beginners and intermediates- where a much better skill is to learn how to avoid difficulties but swapping to another way of saying things- or just learning difficult structures for passive understanding rather than active use. (for instance avoiding the PassÃ© Simple- and using perfect tense + imperfect/ or avoiding structures with the subjunctive, like -je dois aller, instead of - il faut que j'aille, etc).

Where in zurich are you? There is a 'Cafe International' in Egg once a month where you can practice German and take your kids if you have them. Also I once went to an international meetup in Seebach also for this reason, so check with your Gemeinde they might have something or support you in setting something up.

post:
It happens occassionally on the forum where people try to air other peoples dirty laundry and these threads never end well.   
Considering you opened such a thread as your first post, doesn't give you any credit whatsoever as to your intentions or otherwise.     
You want a helpful post, then here's one:   
When you allow trust to disintegrate to a point you search for confirmation, you only ever make things harder on yourself.   
It's not important what the text says, what is important is that trust has been broken and you are looking for some sort of 'confirmation' for what you already assume.   
You are only feeding your insecurity by trying to find evidence that you are right. Feeding this insecurity only makes you feel more shit..... and when you DO find the evidence - then you feel even more shit.   
So why punish yourself?   
What you should do is confront the person directly about this, particularly if you haven't "snooped" through a phone and someone has read this to you.   
If you don't trust the person after you have dealt with the person, then WTF are you doing with them?   
My advice,  
let the message go and deal with it face to face.

Well there is another argument, you are married, right? Since couples complete one return and file together, this would mean your spouse would also need to give this right.    
I think you would be well within your rights to let the designated firm complete the return, then you check it over in detail before signing and submit it directly. No vollmacht given. If they won't agree then complete it yourself.    
I have always found the tax department to be quite open to answering questions.   
BUT, when we lived in Asia there was zero chance we could file and submit our own tax return. The company handled this for us. I provided my information to my husband's employer. There really was no other option.

post: Shouldn't that be "cÃ¹nch of bÃ¹nts"?

I just went through discussing relocation via e-mail with a bunch of people (in English). It generally went like this: 
- I email them using the formal English letter style (Dear Mr/Mrs LastName/Yours sincerely or if I wasn't sure of their name, Dear Sir/Madam / Yours faithfully) 
- they email back formally but with Best/Kind regards at the end 
- I email in the same way 
- they reply with "Dear FirstName/Best regards" or "Kind regards"   
This has happened 3-4 times so far, so I'm now assuming this is the standard once a few emails have been exchanged. I wonder if it's the same when emailing in German.   
In the UK, I started the same but the greetings quickly turned into "Hello FirstName" with "Best regards" or "Kind regards" at the end.

A good language course is only the starting point, but if your aim is to be able to speak German fluently you must get exposure to the language as much and as frequent as possible. Talk in German whenever possible, even when you feel embarrassed by your poor skills. Read, read, and listen... 
I studied French and English in school, and had a very basic knowledge of  German before moving here but now I am ready  for the C1  level exam.  It is possible, but you have to put some effort into this, constantly.
Have you considered a private tutor?  It will be more expensive but can target exactly the areas you need to work on.

post:
you will not find learning materials from English to Swiss German that are worth much.  if you are serious about learning the language, I would start with standard German A1 and purchase one of the excellent learning books that are available from standard German to Swiss German.  With effort you can get sufficiently though A2 in standard German in about 3-6 months to start muddling through the learning materials into Swiss German.   
in the meantime, watch as much tv as you can, there is all kinds of Swiss German tv and comedy programming on youtube, for example:
My colleagues use Swissing ( ) for Swiss German and they are very happy with them.

Valid point by @adrianlondon about not needing to be over-pedantic in a quick follow-up message. That said, @debra says something important here that most job hunters get wrong (particularly at the younger end of the scale).    
Most people involved in recruitment will recognise this problem. If I'm looking for someone to fill that sales or techie role (or whatever), I want to know if this person will help me and the company do the job. If we can help them develop their skills and experience along the way, well that's nice, but it's not why we are looking for a new person to join us.   
To the OP -- please don't take this as a criticism. In fact, I am trying to help.  I wish you good luck in your search.

Okay, good news and bad news... Do you know Radio Eriwan? This is a lot like that.   
Good News: They do, in fact pay for German courses. 
Bad News: You need to be officially unemployed for that.   
Good News: Being unemployed is not too difficult. 
Bad News: In order to qualify as officially unemployed you'll have to have worked in Switzerland for a number of days. Unless there are different rules for recent immigrants.   
Good News: They might actually pay all of it. 
Bad News: They will make you apply for and take any job that sortakinda fits your profile.   
Good News: That's not a bad thing. 
Bad News: There aren't any bookstores that are not only willing to hire someone who barely speaks any German in St. Gallen. There's the RÃ¶sslitor, who is part of the Orell FÃ¼ssli group. Huge bookstore, full of twits, has everything but books and ridiculous requirements as to qualifications of their staff. That's pretty much the only bookstore that pays decent wages. There's also Comedia down the Katharinengasse. They struggle to survive. They have struggled to survive for the past decade or so.    
Good News: I'm fresh out of good news. 
Bad News: Bookshops aren't your best bet, currently. Orell FÃ¼ssli (aka. Big Bookstore Chain #1) is having a fusion with Thalia (aka. Big Bookstore Chain #2). So personnel cuts are expected.   
There. Bleak and dreary a perspective. Should you go to the RAV and talk to them about your German course. Do not mention that you want to go to work in a Bookshop. Go with "I want to do what I have qualifications in".

post:
individual examples aside, I have found that Germans are a lot less likely to want to converse in English and so stick to German.  It's almost impossible to stop Swiss people flicking over to English and you have to actively ask them to keep to German.  It was a nightmare in the early days when I was trying to learn.  It's not a criticism because it was done out of kindness as their language skills were far superior to mine at the time, but I needed that kick up the arse to help me learn German.   
Fortunately, I have some lovely Swiss friends that refuse to speak English to me and mercilessly tease me if I make mistakes but we're usually all pissed on schnapps by then so my German is fluent.   
As is my Arabic, Spanish, Cantonese and Klingon...

Hi everyone! The problem here is that you are mistaking "adjectives" for "adverbs" and expressions of quantity. Grand(e) / neuf/ neuve are adjectives, so you never use the preposition "de" with them. But if you are using an expression of quantity, there you use "de": trop de / beaucoup de / un verre de /une grande quantitÃ© de ... and so on!  
Hope it helps!

Hahahaha, good one. Basically, you either orientate yourself by looking at people who do work, because I suspect you know people who have worked. Or you go for the timeless greetings.   
But, see, the thing is that there are no rules for when one thing starts and when another ends. I know it's very unswiss, but it's not like "Morgen lasts from Midnight to exactly 10.23am."   
If it's to say "Let's meet tomorrow morning" or something, then assume that it's Morgen until noon, Nachmittag until dusk, Abend until you go to bed.
Don't believe you and this isn't a free translation service

reputation: annoyed a few people around here

post:
Hi there,   
I did it. I went to Berlin for two weeks in July, had intensive german classes and went on excursions with the school.   
I stayed with a host, but she was talking too fast all the time with me even if I asked her to slow down, she said she doesn't do that, that it was like that. I had trains running under my window until midnight and starting again at 4am, and all the night through at weekends. So, if you go, ask details about the bedroom and its surroundings!   
Some of the other student had either the same problem, or the host people were not always here in the evening etc.. Depending on your level, I would recommend you to ask to stay with a family with children. They tend to be more patient and to speak slower.   
About the school, DID institut, it was really really hot in the classroom, no air conditioning and with the windows opened, we were annoyed by the noise outside. Most of the students were young and partying in the evening which means that during the class, they were a bit disconnected, shy to speak etc.. But teachers were very good and very well prepared.   
Between students, we were talking most of the time in English as our level of German was not enough to always say what we wanted to say.   
The city in itself is very interesting and captivating. But having, said that, I am not entirely convinced that it's the best way to learn German.    
However, if you are thinking about going there, you can PM me to have more details on which questions to ask the school.

Ok, it's finally come to this, begging for help.    
I have a little amateur history project going which involves correspondence interviews with people around the world. One of the sources is an alderly German gentlemen. He can write in good English, and his wife, in her eighties I imagine, has impeccable Queen's English in a way that puts most people here to shame. So corresponding is going fine. However, he'd previously written some of his experiences down in a German magazine, which he photocopied and posted to me.    
I have tried translating it via google translate but that's a mammoth task to retype it. It's about four pages.   
So if you have good German, and would enjoy summarizing the article into English that would be a fantastic help. An interest in history or military history would be handy too.      
Please pm me if you are interested in helping.

The usual recommendation seems to be to learn High German first. You can do courses in Swiss German here in Basel, but they usually require you to have B1 level High German. If you want to study Swiss German as a linguist, the materials would generally be written in High German too.   
That said, your case is a bit different, having a Baslerin for a girlfriend, but I wonder whether you might find it easier to establish a basis in High German before you arrive. It's easier to find materials and it is useful for learning Swiss German later.

post: I listen to SRF4, a 24 hour Swiss news station, but obviously covers international affairs. I find it great for keeping up to date and keeping 'in tune' with German. The German spoken is generally High German, sometimes an interviewee will speak with a strong local accent or perhaps even in dialect. I play this channel on my tablet/phone using the TuneIn app...
Not really, but I can tell you to avoid "Latitudes". It's OK when used in class but crap for self-study.

Right. There are those rare cases, often somewhat unexpected, like, for instance, the first time I heard Michiganders say, "Have a nice one" (read: day), which exactly corresponds to Swiss German "Heb en schÃ¶ne" (read: Tag), or, "I haven't the faintest / foggiest" (read: idea), like Swiss German "I han kein blasse" (read: Schimmer).    
However, the similarities between phrasal verbs in English and separable verbs in German immediately fade away when it comes to slightly more complicated sentences, where the second part of the phrasal verb automatically gets moved next to the verb, whereas in German there can be lightyears between the two parts.    
Examples: "She   him  " / "Sie   ihn  ." But: "She   just about everybody" / "Sie   absolut ausnahmslos jeden, der ihr zu irgendeiner Zeit aus beliebigem Grund in die Quere kommt, sei es jemand aus der Verwandt- oder Bekanntschaft oder auch ein Wildfremder, mit boshafter HartnÃ¤ckigkeit und unter Einsatz all ihrer ziemlich begrenzten geistigen MÃ¶glichkeiten  ."    
Granted, that monster sentence can be restructured to read, "Sie   absolut ausnahmslos jeden  , der......", which makes things a little bit easier, but the first version is perfectly correct too.    
Greetings from Samuel Longhorne Clemens...

Tips...   
buy an Amazon Kindle and purchase & install German-English as your primary dictionary (google and you'll find plenty of how-to-guides on this).  I found "Collins concise German-English Dictionary" to be the best one available.   This allows you to get a quick translation on any new words quickly just by highlighting/pressing on the word.   
This doesn't work for ipad kindle apps, only true kindles.  With this, it makes it a hell of a lot easier to read normal novels.  I'm at a B2 level and typical Nick Hornby or John Grisham books have been challenging but enjoyable through this.

Go to LEO.org and listen to the pronunciation of each word:   
sechs    
sex       
or ask a German or Swiss German person to help you figure out the difference in sounds.

The use of past tense "thanks for having celebrated this day" is not unusual, but it's mostly used when for little cards on small thank-you-gifts that are sometimes handed out to the guests after or towards the end of the wedding.   
I would personally use present tense but I don't think it's entirely incorrect to say "having spent" on a sign even if it's just a beginning. It just sort of takes it for granted that people will stay for the whole time.
Thanks a lot

I am so with lolly on this one.    
Go ahead to B2, your brain will catch up if it has to.    
I took C1 courses at uni that were organized for B2 exams at the end. The profs who organized it this way knew what they were doing.

What matters is not the actual wealth but how somebody appears to be. There are rich people who behave as if not having more than CHF 100 on their bank-account. And people who have nothing on their account but behave as if ....  but will talk as if being millionaires. But may well tell you

I'm a native speaker of German but I like to hang out here every now and then because I was in the UK for more than a decade before I moved to Switzerland...   
It took me about 3 months before I started to understand my colleagues when they forgot to use high German in conversation ...I might have got there faster but half of my team are native speakers of English and I tend to not watch any Swiss or German TV so make of that what you will.     
If you can improve your German to where you can hold a basic conversation you'll have a much easier time in your day to day interactions.  You'll also be able to cast a wider net socially.  Not speaking German limits you to other English speakers - not that there's anything wrong with the English speaking expat community but as variety is the spice of life it's nice to have the option

To children under 3, sometimes a little longer, there are no such things as pronouns. They take everything as a noun. They hear you called them "du" so they call themselves "du" too when speaking, like a name.  
Just add the name to the du/ich or just correct the child. Every child ends up getting it. No worry whatsoever, noway you can push it either.

Attempt at a diplomatic answer:   
Dear OP, just learn French in Lausanne as much and as long as you want. No problem. The prosody is a bit different but there are many of those within France too. Just watch TV regularly and you'll pick up the main stream accent if you really feel that vaudois French is too special. When you've become fluent in French, you'll notice the 20-30 words typical of Lausanne/Switzerland that are not understood in France and you'll manage to adapt to that too. But that's a question for advanced learners. Don't worry about it now.   
But I wouldn't care at all. French in Lausanne is perfectly fine. Don't loose time thinking about it. Just start learning.   
_________________________

Dear OP, before you are in a position to ask yourself how your Lausanne French sounds to French ears, you'll have to loose your original accent (English?). That will keep you busy a while.

Potentially, a diploma can allways be of any help; it shows your comptences in a particular field.   
Now, it would be preferable if the one you mention would be focused on the European Language Portfolio; this system has got a normative value throughout EU both for educations institutions as for employers. In other words, it should document your competences according to the EU Language Portfolio. If not, I'd advise to choose another provider for your English course. 
Here's more info:     
Good luck

post:
You are right when you say it will take a little longer, but since you are here, why waste the time learning at home? Go out and talk to the natives!   
I spent my first year in Munich doing what you are doing and being frustrated. It was only after I found opportunities to immerse myself did my german really start to improve. Head down to Zeughauskellar and talk to some locals; go down to the flea market on Saturday morning and chat to the folks running the stand; go to a local cafe and bug the people sitting there reading their papers... or whatever. The tip re the post-its is a good one, also, should you have a hobby, why not get together with like-minded folk in your area, I guarantee you they will be thrilled to have someone from abroad who shares their interests. My experience on this front came with a fellow old timer nut and a couple of fellow Oktoberfest freaks - we had things in common, they spoke no English and I wanted to learn German. And it works.    
Chatting on Englishforum may be fun but it will not improve your language skills. Sorry mods.    
I also recommend listening to German talk radio and "reading" German newspapers everyday... out loud if it does not feel too ridiculous. Half of your problem right now is being understood by the locals, any improvement in your pronunciation will really help you out.    
Last tip, be patient and do not worry about sounding like a total fool. Good luck!

post:
My daughter has attended LSI Zurich for 4 months.  She had no knowledge of German when she started.  She likes the school and we are pleased with the progress she has made.  Some of her teachers have been good and others have been better.   So far we can't say she's had a bad teacher (even the subs).   
Back in July, she started in a class already in progress.  At first she felt overwhelmed because everyone else seemed so much more advanced.  She stuck with it and eventually caught up (within ~5 weeks).  After about 12 weeks her class was combined with another class that was about one week ahead of hers.  She was apprehensive about it but, again, within a couple of weeks, students from both classes were at  the same level.  The teachers seem very capable at handling these transitions.   
Also, the school seems to be flexible in allowing you to move up/down a level if need be.     
She has made many friends.  The hardest part is saying goodbye to them when they start new jobs or return to their home countries.    
Based on our experience, I am happy to recommend the school.

I buy my lessons in packages of twelve 60-minute slots for 92  CHF an hour. Once you become a repeat client, you get 8% off. You can  decide if you want to do 45-minute or whatever suits you in length, but  once your 720 minutes are up, then you buy a new package. Once you're in  exam preparation mode, it jumps to 105 CHF an hour. But that usually is  only 4-5 weeks before the exam that you're in that mode.   
I'd say  I worked with my teacher once a week most of the time, but for a few  months it was twice a week. Right before my C1 exam, I was SUPER nervous  and met with her 3-4 times a week. But I still don't think there's any  group course I could have taken to get me from B1 to C1 in 12 months  when I add up how much I paid.

I own hundreds of old pocket calendars in credit card size, issued by banks, insurance companies and other businesses, all from Switzerland, some of them dating back to the 1930. It's not an obsession but the result of a necessitiy caused by another obsession of mine, namely model railroad building, where those thin plastic sheets can serve many purposes.    
As you may imagine, they all have 12 or 15 rectangles, one for each month of the year plus sometimes three more for the last months of the previous year or the first months of the next year. Each month square has five (February sometimes only four) lines, one for each week.    
Without a single exception, they all have Monday as the first day of the week, no matter how far back I go.    
By the way, in the 1950s, we had a silly joke. We asked a class mate, "Do you know what 'Modimidofrsaso' means?" Of course no one knew. "What, you don't know? Are you blind or what? You've seen it so many times!" Take your pocket calender out of the wallet and show them, "Mo Di Mi Do Fr Sa So" (for  ntag,  enstag,  ttwoch" etc.. Duh.

If you go there, you'll be seeing every habitant of the valley. It's very "champester" (no idea how to say that in English: lÃ¤ndlich). Ask people at the Chasa cumÃ¼nala for baby sitting. In these small places, the information is not written down anywhere, everybody just knows or knows who knows. Even if you can't go the whole day, go there are speak to the coordinator (It used to be Mario Pult, no idea whether he is still there), he will be able to help you to get language coaching or courses or something. It's Romansh country, personal contact is everything, forget the formality of the northern Alp-side.   
Remember to say "jau sun" for "I am", not "eu sun", it's important to them, it's a special form. That's where they got their name from: ils Jauers.

post:
The best thing to do would be an intensive German course, full immersion is the way to go and they teach you the grammar which are super important for understanding in German. 
There are some good apps out there for learning German and some really terrible ones. I've tried a heap of them and the biggest recommendation I can make for someone who is just beginning is the Michel Thomas Method (you will see him recommended in other threads). They have made an app for his program, which is expensive but hardly the cost of buying the CDs. The app is Iphone built but it's all audio so the larger layout is not required. It gives you a heap of confidence in speaking fast.  
For a tap and play Ipad app Busuu works well but they are always trying to get more money out of you. I would highly recommend 'German Flash Cards' by Declan Software. Absolutely awesome as it has phased repetition and a bunch of other tricks to make it stick. Get it it's worth it. Avoid 'word power' or 'word bots' they are terrible. The only thing with app programs is they usually give you words, German needs grammar for understanding and learning this alone can be painful. In a class it can actually be fun!  
I hope this helps

I enrolled for the summer school at the University of Geneva many years ago and it was the best course for me to improve my French.   
First they test everyone to provide the right level.  The course is fairly intensive and includes lectures/teaching of grammar etc., language lab to improve pronunciation and some fun add-ons

Caribou is not just the reindeer like animal in Northern QuÃ©bec, it is also something consumed at carnival. Typically a blend of red wine and spirits. After a few shots it does not feel so cold outside.    
By the way the accent is not funny or strange, it is just traditional old Norman and Breton French, unsullied by the Paris intellectuals who changed fin de semaine to "week-end" and stationment to "parking".    
Of course there are always a few good natured misunderstandings, such as "Ne touche pas Ã  ma blonde" Which a Belgian would interpret as "don't touch my beer" and the QuÃ©becois knows is "leave my girlfriend alone".

thread: A little help with a short translation please

post:
I'm not a translator...   
But I am a native English speaker and I think that passage needs some work to improve the quality of the English before you start translating it into French.    
For starters, what is it supposed to be? An advert, a mission statement, or a 'what we believe' statement? To be honest I can't decide if the passage is supposed to be chatty or formal in tone - it is an uncomfortable mix of the two. Your sentences are too long, poorly structured and some of them don't make a great deal of sense.   
If you want help, I suggest you provide more information about what you are trying to say, what your target audience is, and what the context is. Then perhaps someone will be able to help you get that paragraph into a paragrapher that is decently-structured, grammatically correct, and that contains vocabulary that is appropriate for your aim and audience.    
You might also consider updating your profile to be a little more specific. I am not inclined to help someone who cannot decide if they are a 'business student', a 'business man' or a 'business owner'. Why? Because I prefer to help people who are upfront about who they are, what they need help with and why they need it. I am under the impression that most of the posters on here feel the same way. If you come back and explain a little more, I'd be happy to try and get your English into better shape. And then perhaps someone might help with the French.

post:
I agree with Stifoan. The Cambrige Proficiency proves you can express yourself in English - but this does not mean you can translate well.    
A learner with a vocabulary of 2000 words can understand 96% of spoken words but only 80% of average written text. A learner with 6000 words understands 90%. However, using them correctly in context is far more difficult. Like asking an equestrian to ride a tiger.    
From Wikipedia, a 1995  study estimated the vocabulary size of first-year college students (high-school educated) at about 12,000, and college-educated speakers at  about 17,000 word families.   
With the help of a dictionary you can be more precise, but only a native speaker can choose easily between close synonyms. "A Swiss with CPE would be quite good  at translating from English into German, but not necessarily the other  way around." I'm an English teacher, but no matter how long I learn German, I will always be very wary of translating into it.   
Check your vocabulary on    
Practice on
