Okay I am going to attempt to post this one more time, since the last two wouldn't post.  Where to start......my name is Tyra and I am in the U.S.  I found this forum due to teasing from a friend.  He would say things to me in what I now lovingly refer to as swissy (Berndeutsch).  He would taunt me with the fact that there was no translator online that could tell me what he was saying.  Well he was wrong........I found all of you here.  lol.  He even gave me the old chuchichaschtli test!  He and I have become rather close in the months that have passed since this has all started.  He is an amazing man.  He calls me Sweetness and his Sunshine, he has told me macht das dsunne schint.  I make his sun shine.  I wanted to impress him so I'd ask for some translations and how to say certain things on this forum.  Unfortunately he has been right though, I don't have many resources.   
I read your thread about the resources for learning swiss german and some of it has proved to be helpful, but very little.  Most of the listed resources are in German then going to Swiss German or they are not the dialect I am looking for.  I also saw your post about tandem language partners but most people are in Switzerland for that. post:
I would recommend Hull's School (at Stadelhofen) or AKAD (in Oerlikon). I did my Lower Cambridge with Hull and my Proficiency with AKAD. Both were great decades ago, and apparently have improved. Migros is tremendous for private correspondence and holiday trips. Mum was at Migros School learning English between 1972 and 2001 and found it splendid. But for university you need the proficiency, and this is quite a different thing. You will get lectured by Cambridge educated teachers, who may be humourous but mean serious business. It is not easy work to get the Proficiency Certificate but you learn a lot, not just about English but even about how to teach other people in a senseful way, about English culture, about how to behave in the English speaking world, about business, and more. A lot of work but worth any minute.    
From HÃ¶nggerberg, AKAD may be nearer, the question however is where you work. And S-Bahn trains from HardbrÃ¼cke to Stadelhofen need less than 10 minutes. So that both options are open. Locationwise, my preference would be Hull

Proof of financial means for subsistence and travel expenses is submitted via:   
Bank statements or a statement of guarantee by a solvent person residing in the canton of application. The guarantor attaches, as evidence of his/her (financial) means, his/her latest tax bill, pay slips for the last three months, and a statement from the debt enforcement office [note: this is an official document, a "Betriebungsauskunft", from the cantonal "Betreibungsamt", proving that no one lays claim to the person's property due to non-payment of a debt].   
If the residency is denied on the basis of the applicant's own resources:    
Confirmation (is required) from a financial institution registered in Switzerland from which it is clear that sufficient funds for this purpose are available.

post:
Thank you for your help everyone - and sorry for the delay in replying - I have been reading your replies but have been struggling to keep on top of tasks this week!   
Interestingly several people seem to struggle to understand what I mean by breath hitching. Perhaps it is not a common phrase. Or perhaps I'm loosing my English...   
To try and clarify, the best explanation I can give is that I I use the phrase 'hitching' to describe a sensation I often experience which is very similar to a series of gentle hiccups in my chest - without the 'hic'! So my breath comes short, slightly faster than usual and in an irregular pattern. But it is not due to overexertion, anxiety or being upset - hence why I want to avoid saying my breath is catching in my chest which for me (in English) implies a more obvious breathing problem generally linked to an physical or emotional cause.    
(As an aside, if you really want to refine your English and French vocabulary in the areas of emotions and physical sensations, a 20 week CBT group will provide an excellent training... and if you do 3 such groups, you will find yourself pondering minute details of vocabulary as described above on a regular basis)!    
I think that the 'chatouiller' suggestion might be best, as to me that sounds the least dramatic! Or someone offline suggested I simply said 'J'ai la respiration irreguliÃ¨re'.    
Thank you again - for nothing else, for demonstrating to me once again that we all identify and describe our physical sensations in different ways.    
Now to go and do tonight's exercises!

post:
Absolutely not! We love it when you try our language, no matter how bad your pronunciation is. And most Swiss are really happy to hear something nice about our language, or even see people trying to learn it, boosts our self-confidence a bit.   We don't really like it getting compared to German too much, or hearing that it sounds similar. So if you want to say something nice just say it sounds a bit similar to Dutch, something the Dutch themselves would agree to as well. Have never witnessed any bad reaction from Swiss when exposed to foreigners trying to speak Swiss German, and I interact with quite a lot of foreigners on a daily basis in both work and private life. Be prepared to be made fun of though, and don't take it to heart, it just really sounds funny/lovely to us.  
It seems like most Swiss really have a huge deficit when it comes to speaking about their language, so chances are you'll get an hour-long lecture about the differences in dialects and how this and that canton speaks a nice/ugly accent.

post:
Few people learn languages "automatically" and to learn another language if done thoroughly IS work. I have taken up a paid assignment as a private German teacher once per week. The student is a Latin American lady who came to CH 8 years ago and has a 6 years old son who speaks  fluently Swiss German but of course not yet Standard German. When being there I throughout the hour strictly keep to Standard German, and try to bring a bit of grammar and structure into her German language mess. She does not lack intelligence at all, but I strongly suspect that she never learnt proper Spanish grammar either. Another aspect to be cared about is prononciation(s) and regional variations.    
I have done such teachings for apprentices in our company in the 80ies in German, French and English.  The problem was that they, majority-wise of Italian origin, spoke Swiss German perfectly well and were better in French in a general way then their native Swiss colleagues, but missed structures, grammar and spelling. Critical was the situation with English, as in aircargo your professional (legally binding) language IS English, and not just a "bla-bla Swinglish English" but a correct one. Things did not arrive with those teachers of the Commercial School of KV-Z really well, so that action was needed.    
My grandfather (mother-side) language-wise was good but a bit the "victim" of his father (my grand-grandfather) who had lived for roughly a decade in the USA, but had returned in the late 1870ies and married. AND demanded of his son fairly early to learn properly English, which was not excactly easy at the time. He then had to ride by train to ZÃ¼rich in the evening twice per week and when needing more of it on one side in the 1920ies bought some of the earliest "audio" things available, and had one radio tuned on the BBC and listened to BBC broadcasts and to speeches of people like Lloyd George, Ramsay McDonald, and Neville Chamberlain. He by some self-courses also learnt Italian, and so was the correspondent in his company for English, French and Italian. He improved his linguistic proficiencies by meeting Englishmen, Frenchmen and Italians while on holidays in the Alps, sitting together with them until midnight.    
He of course heavily encouraged the enthusiasm of his daughter for other languages

Thanks all.   
So we're not cursed then lol

There is another offer. This time it's for an online language course.       
I am thinking of buying myself one of those offers to learn a new language (spanish maybe?) but am not too sure about learning a new language from scratch with an online course.

When I was learing German in college, I had one teachter from Austria who played us a tape of what Swiss-German sounded like. There's no way you can even learn it without being there. The best you can do is learn southern German, like Austrian or Bavarian. For some reason it's also hard to find a German teacher in the schools around the world who happens to be from Switzerland. The closest thing you can do to learning Switzerland's languages before living there is to learn German from Austrians and to learn French from Belgians. Or Italian from people from Northern Italy. Those are the places people have to be from before they'll bother to remember to tell you, "Oh by the way, this is what Switzerland says..." or "this is how it's done in Switzerland..."    
The best I was able to do was get out the Austrian that Switzerland always uses the ss instead of that symbol that HochDeutsch uses (I don't even have it on this keyboard) and says Sonnabend like Austria instead of Samstag. On the French side, the best I could get was that they use the original-Latin words for seventy and ninety like Belgium (septante and nonante) instead of saying "sixty-ten" and "four-twenty-ten" like France. This far I got from learning French from Belgians.    
The countries around it whose languages it shares, all seem to treat it like it's not even there, or that its "variation" of the language in question is somehow "not correct." I had a German teacher from Berlin who seemed not to even remember that Switzerland is even THERE, somehow. I'm in Quebec now, so don't get me started on how the French treat Switzerland regarding their shared language...!
Thanks anyway, I appreciate all your help - Squinting Lotti

post:
I right now give German lessons to a lady from Latin America, who does not hesitate to speak in German, but whose grammar and structure in German was a bit of a mess, and so, I concentrated my efforts on grammar. Many German teachers, even North Germans, however have a meagre command of grammar and so rather avoid than tackle grammar which is widely regarded as boring, while it is the skeleton of a language. I do not believe that there are any schools with "Deutsche Grammatik" classes, while there are teachers who give more or less emphasis to grammar.   
What you mention about your talking problem in fact obviously is a mental and psychological problem. You possibly when going to such places like those lessons should relax more and take it easier. I in secondary class had a teacher who, under a bit "shady" pretenses on specific days picked on me and "condemned" me to an "extra-hour" after 4pm. It was his Italian lesson, he gave me some nice stuff to work on, which I even could take home with me. And then, as he knew that I from holidays had quite some command in practical Italian, when those students got "stucked" suddenly asked me  "how would YOU say it" and I then replied "well, simply  ........"  .  And I took the most simple way possible.  Which, as Dr.Dr. R.M. stated, was THE way to go. So, back again, relax and take it easy.  Do not try to be perfect, but try to communicate. Do not feel frustrated when/if the teacher corrects you.

post:
It seems  strange to me, that the term "lotrecht" is used in the context of maths (where normally "rechtwinklig" or "orthogonal" would be used).   
A "Lot" is a tool which is mostly used to determine wheter a wall is pependicular to the ground or not. In its simplest form it is just a string which a weight attached. "Lotrecht" litterally means the direction into which the Lot is pointing (i.e. the direction of gravity.) 
According to wikipedia the corresponding English term is vertical direction.    
It seems though that in Geometry the therm Lot is used (altougth I never heard it in this context before). In which case it just means a line which is perpendicular to an other line.   
The term Senkrecht is a bit ambigious it is actually synonymos to "Lotrecht" (it derived from the word "Senkblei" which is onother word for "Lot") and means the vertical direction.   it is on the same time often used to express that two lines are perpendicular to each other (here "rechtwinklig" or "orthogonal" would be better choices). It seems as if the teacher did not pick the best termology.
Just add "li" to any noun. ;-)

post:
I did the intensive, month-long CELTA several years ago. The biggest challenge for us was cramming all the prep and assignments into those 4 weeks - with theory in the mornings, that often meant CELTA-ing 14 hours a day. Hopefully you won't suffer the same pressure with the 3 month one!   
Overall though, a brilliant learning experience, and my biggest worry - having your fellow students and tutor observing /critiquing - was soon forgotten. I learnt masses, despite having years of observation/teaching experience to begin with (as a Teaching Assistant).   
I didn't completely agree with the marking scheme - e.g. rapport was one box to tick, but given equal value to every other box - e.g. presentation of materials. That meant that a guy in our group, with zero connection to any of the students and whose class everyone dreaded, got the second highest grade, having ticked enough boxes in other categories. But.. that's a minor gripe!   
The very detailed tutor report at the end is really useful. Just don't lose your certificate. I've heard they are irreplaceable.    
Good luck

Free French lessons... I think it depends what you mean by 'expat'.   
If you are here with a job (or with someone who has a job), and therefore have an income, then I doubt very much you will get something for free. I would imagine the same thing applies if you are a student.    
If you are out of work, then you   be entitled to a free language course (talk to your ORP advisor or social worker).    
If you are on a low income, or in a 'precarious situation', and are not able to benefit from other French classes, you may be able to get help from these people:  . The classes are not free, but they are very cheap.    
If none of these options apply / appeal, you could post a request for a langauge exchange on  . I think that you might also be able to find someone studying at UNIL or EPFL for a language exchange... A friend of mine did this (and ended up marrying her language exchange partner, but that's another story). I don't know exactly where she found the ad though, sorry.    
Hope that helps.

I just asked my husband, who is a primary school teacher. He said it takes a lot of practice, regardless, even if the child does not have dyslexia, so try to make it fun and don't get too stressed about it.   
I know at my preschool/primary school they had a plastic clock with moveable hands, and a clock stamp where you could make the clock face and then draw on the hands to whatever you wanted, and name them.   
When making the switch from English to German, they say 'half to' the hour whereas we say 'half past' - so 'halb 2' is 13:30. One of the first things my husband did as a new english teacher for the primary schoolers was to make sure they could all tell the time and say the time in english properly... because it's pretty confusing.    
I bet there are heaps of computer games online that teach the time...
thread: Teaching English to a dyslexic 11 year old - tips needed!

post:
We own   I found it to be a useful resource and read it before the birth of our first.   
We choose to operate as a OPOL (One Parent, One Language) household. No matter where we live or where we are, I speak exclusively in English with our children and my husband speaks exclusively in Swiss German. As a matter of politeness, when guests are at the table with us, we speak predominantly in the least common denominator language. However, when telling my daughter to, "sit down properly" or other manners things, I'll still speak to her in English.   
Before we moved to Switzerland when she was just shy of 2.5, she was fluent with her understanding, but spoke back almost always in English. Personally, I wanted my husband to push her more to speak back, but he didn't think it was necessary and her Swiss German is not under my control.   
When we moved here, it took about six weeks before she was fluent in both speaking and listening. The real turning point was when we went on a week long vacation with another Swiss German family. The intensity of that experience really helped her spoken language blossom.   
Then in October, we went back to the US and it worked the same way in reverse. The intensity of two weeks in an English speaking environment resulted in yet another language explosion in English.   
My daughter has always been extremely very verbal in English and she began early. I found that as she started speaking more and more Swiss German, she followed the same path in regards to the extent of her vocabulary and ways that she uses it.   
*****   
I have put a lot of thought into how to do bilingualism in my household and have considered a lot of methods. I always ask other bilingual families how they do it and bilingual adults what they did and didn't like about the experience growing up. I've come to the conclusion that there are many, MANY ways to raise bilingual children. You have to figure out what makes most sense for YOUR family. It also very much depends on the child. My daughter loves to talk and loves to express herself. I am not at all shocked by her fluency and how long it took. It's just the way she is. Other children are shy or some don't want to say a word until they know it's perfect. What works for one, may not work or simply may not make sense for your family. In the book that I linked above, there are many examples as well.   
*****   
Direct to your question, I once read on the forum about a family who introduced a doll to their child during bathtime or something like this. This doll could only understand Swiss German. Apparently this was a non-threatening way for the child to practice and during a limited period of time so it wasn't overwhelming. I liked that idea and have put it in my toolbox if I ever need it.   
Hope that helps!

post:
when I was in language school back in the dark ages of the late 20th century, we practiced routinely to speak "about myself".     
We started first by writing our little biography, starting with where we were born, where we grew up, went to school, something about our families, hobbies, interests, and plans for the future.    
Once you have it all written out, you can go through and edit it for content, grammar and structure.    
Then you basically just memorize it.

post: That's a good one...

I did an "understanding Swiss German" course at the Volkshochschule in Basel.  It was really good.  Although it was entitled "understanding", we were also encouraged to speak it a bit, although it was fine if people only wanted to stick to German as well (but saying things out loud does help get them in your head I find).   
You had to have a minimum of B1 german to do the course, and I discovered that my greatest problem was understanding the other participants, most of whom came from Northern Germany and had a quite inpenetrable accent (well to me anyway!)   
There was not a class where I didn't think "oh wow, that's what that means .." so it was really worth while.  As we are in Basel, it was Basler SG, but as I come from the depths of Baselland, the teacher tried to differentiate where he knew things were said a little differently round us.   
All in all, would warmly recommend it.

Well, you could post a tandem request (first thread in the language corner) and exchange language skills.

Concerning the short time period, an intensive language course could be necessary.

Even much cuter in Schaffhauser dialect: "Da da da taar!" Same in some parts of Thurgau.      According to new (= reformed) orthography, it's "dass" also in German German (in Swiss German standard it was already since the 1930's). And "Schifffahrt" with three f's is only logical and a simplification compared to the old system of "Pressspan" with three s's but "Pressack" with two, althoug it is a composite of "Press-" and "Sack).    
I don't like the reformed orthography, but there are things that are substantially simpler and clearer now.

I don't know any Bavarian nor any Austrian that can speak Hochdeutsch without revealing their true origine. And that's NORMAL. Same with Swiss. Keep your accent, it's natural. It can still be perfectly correct High German. A fellow (very) Swiss teacher speaks dialect only to the cleaning ladies, otherwise I've never heard her speaking anything else than perfect High German... she however pronounces   with a long /o:/, like "ohp" that's quite disturbing but still, she has the nicest High German south of the Neckar.    
Swiss High German is perfectly fine. Local specificities are normal, and it's not any different in High German north of the Rhine (and of Schafhausen).   
Frankly, one hears usually quite clearly when a German comes from Schleswig or an old Hamburg fellow. They also have their own High German sometimes.

And it is similar in case of TV, where also those in crime-stories where the Dative gets gradually eliminated. I think that the Genitive in German language in a not too distant moment will be something for the linguism-scientists.

Just in case somebody wants to know: LENGTH OF VOWELS   
- First part: Vowels are long when followed by single consonant, short when followed by double consonant  
NOTE: ck, tz are "doubles" and ch is ambiguous as it can not be written double   
- Second part: Vowels are long when specifically elongated by -h or double-vowel. 
NOTE: Double-vowels are mostly low-German northern words that somehow found their way into the High German dictionary.  
EXCEPTION: IE. When comming from monophtongason of old ie pronounced /iÃ¤/ like in modern Swiss-German, the old spelling ie stayed for the new long vowel.   
- Third part: Elongation with -h (Dehnungs-H) is not specified before voiced occlusives (b,d,g) as the elongation always finds place in the official version of high-German (northern German accent keeps the old short vowels), the only exception being the absence of elongation in one low German word with low German spelling kept in Ebbe.   
- Fourth part: in -IEH-the h is not a Dehnungs-H but a remain of the shift due to Verner's law (hence shift h/g in ziehen/zog and h/ch in Vieh/Viecher)   
- Fifth part: Regional pronounciation may have kept the old short vowels, it's especially the case in the two extremes low-German and Swiss-German. Standart BÃ¼hnendeutsch however have consistent elongation of vowels in syllables with voiced consonant that where open originally at middle-high-German stage. With unvoiced consonant in that configuration, the vowel normally stays short and the spelling is double consonant.

Hi, 
depending on your needs you may consider this option or a similar company :        
I am very sorry if i take away work from locals and EFs but for what i needed this company was a better option. Top journals in my field (fluid dynamics) are suggesting it together with others companies. I have used their services to edit my PhD thesis and it saved me several headaches.    
It is targeting academics that need help editing their English for technical papers. It is cheaper and much faster than any local editor and the paper will be edited by somebody with direct experience in your field.     
Locals editors that i had experience with had an amazing English but not technical enough to meet my advisor 'standards'. Here i have to say that my advisor is reeaaaalllly picky about it, and my field is quite technical and mathematical ... Moreover, local editors were not alway able to understand the deep logic of the period thus they were slightly changing the meaning and the logical implications of the sentences.     
Obviously, local editors have their major advantages (usually targeting different kind of customer, more flexibility, more personal interactions etc etc ) and you have to evaluate by yourself what do you really need and which is your best option.    
I have no conflict of interest with the cited company.    
good luck

post:
I'd say "Nein, danke" is more frequent than "Danke, nein," but the important thing in both cases is the "no." However, when there is no "no," as in the case of "Danke, ich muss noch fahren," things can get confusing for those who are not familiar with such peculiarities.     
It's not a Swiss or German problem, though. Such misleading situations can happen in just about any language. During my first months in Greece, I had to learn all sorts of such subtleties. Like, when you say, "Den katalaveno," ("I don't understand"), that means you don't understand the language, but when you say, "Den katalava" ("I have not understood" -- yes, sounds silly, but there is no really equivalent translation for the Greek aoristos), it means, "Pardon me?" I learned that during my first hour in Greece.    
On our little island, when the proprietor of one of those picturesque taverns on the waterfront asks me, "Do you want to have a beer?", that means he is treating me to it. If I tried to pay afterwards, I'd badly offend him. If, on the other hand, he asks, "What do you want to drink?", he's expecting a normal order.

post:
, it is designed to provide some background information on some of the grammatical constructs used in English. Why? Knowledge of how certain things work in English can be directly applied when learning other foreign languages.      (for people who didn't go to school)      - A doing word e.g. run, jump, laugh, speak, be, have, become.    - A word which describes a verb e.g. quickly, slowly, patiently.    - A person, place or thing e.g. computer, internet, John, Zurich.    - Describes a noun e.g. big, small, smart, stupid.    - Replaces nouns indicating people e.g. I, me, you, him, her, they, them, myself.    - modifies noun and verb phrases e.g. for, with, at, on, below, through, around, by.       
Nominative case is simply a fancy name for the  of a sentence. Consider the sentence:       
The subject of the sentence is the dog. It's the part of the sentence that is performing the action (verb). Therefore we say that "The dog" is in nominative case.       
Accusative is also a fancy name for the   of a sentence. The object receives the action from the verb. So in our sentence above, the boy is the object.       
In English our sentence patterns are often formed with specific word order. Generally it is very easy for us to tell which part of the sentence is subject and object simply because the  subject  usually comes first, followed by a  verb , followed by the  object . Colours have been used to illustrate the point.         Other languages use different word order. Some may have an almost fixed pattern like English, and others may have variable order depending on the other elements in the sentence. German may be SVO or it may be SOV - in some cases the order of subject or object may be reversed.   
Therefore instead of thinking in terms of word order it is more useful to ask yourself the question "Who is doing what to whom". Who is giving the action, and who is receiving it?     
Consider the following:     
We know that the subject is "I", and "am eating" is the verb, but where is the object? We could imagine that the object is whatever might be in my mouth. So the sentence really looks like:     
What about :     Now the subject seems to be missing - but the person must be talking to someone, so it is most likely:           
Passive voice won't be covered here, it is mentioned only because these types of sentences do not fit into to the normal structure given above. Passive sentences do not contain an object. An example might be:   
Passive voice:  
Active voice:    
When trying to find the subject and object in passive voice the student may become confused, so it is important to at least recognise these types of sentences at this point.       
Can you see the subject and object in these sentences?     Now you can see that "I" is a nominative pronoun, and "me" is an accusative pronoun. Likewise he/she is nominative and him/her is accusative.    
If you are unsure about a sentence, try to rearrange it slightly so you can put "I" or "me" into the sentence. So if you are having trouble with:       
Change it to either:     , or   .   
Now by seeing where "I" or "me" would fit, you can instantly tell which part of the sentence is nominative and which part is accusative.       
Nominative and accusative case are not difficult, but unless you have a basic understanding of what they mean and how they work you will probably find that you can never progress past a certain point in the foreign language you are trying to learn. An understanding of how they work in your native language will be very important if you wish to also use them effectively in another European language.   
You may wish to consider reading part two in this series -   [internal link].

post: Also another option is to look for tandem learning over Skype. Websites like   help you find people (in person too).
FWIW, I've been happy with the   (2nd edition):

From the student side, having tried both, I must admit I always enjoyed the group lessons more. In the 1:1 situation I felt far too self conscious and kind of stupid - at least with others there I felt like I wasn't alone in my stupidity  (and realised that actually I was quite good compared to some of the others  ).    
Even though the teacher was very nice I just didn't enjoy the 1:1 situation. I imagine it depends on you as much as the teacher, but why not try both and see which you prefer?   
The most important part for me was being able to practice outside of classes, because my work was in English and pretty much everyone I knew spoke English. For that I'd highly recommend enrolling in some kind of other practical adult education class - like cookery or painting or DIY, to give you a chance to just hear the language being spoken in a normal setting outside of German class. Make it something where you can follow by copying - so not German literature or something, but anything where there will be practical work as well as listening. I learnt to drive here which did wonders for my German! Also, watch German TV as much as you can stand - start with something like the news (where they generally speak clearly!) or sports programs if you're into football or something.

post:
You will get there.  These things take time.  Most imporatantly that I have seen in people is that you are seen to be making an effort to communicate and learn how to communicate with them.   
I have travelled a lot all over the world over the last 3 years and often find myself in situaitons where I don't understand the majority language being spoken.  I have adopted the following tactics:   
I see if I can pick up the thread of the convesation and then if I feel that I have something to contribute, I will chip in and put my point across in English.....always prefixed by a polite "excuse me but are you talking about .... ".  People will make a lot of allowances if you have something to contribute to a conversation and and often this can lead to you learning a lot as they explain what was being said and you can relate it to what you thought was being said.   
Occasionally feel free to chip in with the odd humourous    You need to pick the right circumstances for this one and read the crowd.  Sometimes they will give you a couple of minutes of English conversation.  Once again, the more you wow them with your conversational skills, the more they will make an extended effort to educate your into how to communicate with them.   
The more you hear "Dude, you really need to learn German." or the such, the more they are telling you that they want to help you.   
We are social creatures by nature, all embarressed by these situations and our languages.  A little humour and witty conversation and ice breakers always goes a very long way.

post: This wasn't in Switzerland, but when I was in MontrÃ©al I took a ride up to the top of the observation deck at Olympic Stadium. One of the attendants noticed that I was wearing an Expos cap and asked me about the Washington Nationals. His English wasn't perfect, but he understood me until I said that as far as the Nats were going, we fans were "waiting for the other shoe to drop." Is there another idiom in French that means the same thing as expecting bad news to come?

In regards to torrents: Get Nod32 or equivalent and read comments to each torrent. There problem solved.   
As for the original question, I've used Pimsleur for a few langauges and have found that the retention rate is quite high for everything you do. Downside is even after a few levels your vocabulary is quite low (less than 1000) but you should remember all of it. It's more for conversations rather than true knowledge of a language and you never see the words your learning so you can't learn to read. It starts off with Hi, how are you, good, where do you live, what, what do you want to eat, with me, with you, etc simple things but useful. 
If your an audio learner then it works well, if your visual well.....   
Rosetta Stone: I've never used it myself however from my understanding it's based on a picture/word approach similar to a site like livemocha.com (which is free, try it out). So you see a picture of a horse and the software says Cheval and you associate Cheval with a horse. And repeat.

Moving to a new country with a new language because of one partners job, is strenuous for the other partner who may find it difficult to integrate, find new friends, and generally just figure out how things work in the new home. Especially if you dont speak the language.   
The  is a school that is supported by the "Migration Department" (government), and is currently enrolling students for the next semester of German courses.   
The good thing about these courses is that they offer childcare while the course is on.     
Different locations throughout Switzerland:     
I know primarily about the one in  , where children are looked after at the  .   
Give it a go- you meet new people, are able to talk to your neighbours, and find friends/people you actually want to be with rather than just the ones with a common language to you(!) 
Tell the parter to give it a go too.     (No, i don't work for these guys, I just believe that integration and making friends for all family members makes for a happier life in a new place.)

post:
"Ich habe einen Frosch im Hals"; I think the same saying exists in English, but if there are not only English speakers in your class it still might be interesting for them...   
So let's get on to the more interesting parts of anatomy:   
Jemanden Zucker in den Arsch blasen - "to blow sugar into someones ass" - meaning: to suck up to someone.   
Jemanden geht der Arsch auf Grundeis - "someones hitting anchor ice with his ass" - meaning: somebody is "shitting bricks"    
Jemanden schein die Sonne aus dem Arsch - the sun is shining from someones... - meaning: somebody is very happy.   
Jemanden mit dem Arsch ins Gesicht springen - to jump ass-ahead into somebody's face - meaning: threaten/attack somebody...     
Your teacher is going to love me for this...

On a visit to Prague, it was in 1991, I made the experience that almost everybody spoke German remarkably well.  And yes, with languages it depends on the language in question and you yourself. I always find Spanish fairly easy even if I never really learnt it, but Portuguese rather difficult. In Turkish, when trying some words in Turkish I tend to pronounce the Arab way, which they do not like at all. And as German is spoken by so many Turks in so many places so excellently, no problem. Greek is a language which is not mine, but as so many Greeks speak English, no problem. Hebrew is relatively easy, except that many words in Hebrew have quite a different meaning from the same word in Arabic, which irritate. But as virtually all Israelis speak English and amazingly many German, this also is no problem. Interesting was, when I had to make phone-calls to Argentina, the questions "do you speak English" "parlez-vous FranÃ§ais" lead to nowhere, but "parliate Italiano"  had quite a positive result fairly often.

I very nearly put in "bargee" instead of "bhaji", having lived closer to the canal than to the Indian takeaway when I was a kid  .   
14/15 for me anyway...  put too many l's in vermilion.

"Local Gemeinde" is the official office in each town/village.... where all officialdom takes place. 
You just go there and ask about German language courses.  If there is one in the vicinity they will point you at it. 
The link I gave in my previous posting will direct you to your nearest course.     
But the teacher will usually know more than one language - to help a student totally unable to understand a given word! 
My teacher was a Linguist, and spoke very good english, as well as Albanian, Serb, French, Italian, Spanish, and a few other languages as well, but only used them in dire circumstances! He even knew the different Swiss dialects.

I usually vary depending on what type of verb I'm using.   
If I follow it with a verb for a specific type of action, I tend to say "er macht sich" (ans Putzen, an den Abwasch, etc.)   
If not, which is often the case with the phrase "going about," I use "er stellt sich." Meaning, he is going about it in whatever way: 
Er stellt sich dabei unbeholfen an/he's going about this is a clumsy way

I must say I did sleep with a Britt regularly over years but we speak German. Beside English, I confess: intimate relations do boost the whole experience. More speaking time, more understanding, no bullshit answers, intensive practice etc. In one word: quantity.

When we lived in the US I became increasingly frustrated with my older son when I spoke Spanish to him and he answered in English (which happened after he started school).  My frustration led me to speaking more and more English at home and after I while we stopped using Spanish.  Now I regret this almost daily after seeing how easy my kids have learned German...  ! 
I suggest that you keep speaking English to them even if they answer in German, I bet you they are understanding and retaining everything and the speaking part will come later.  Maybe when they get older they'll be more willing to speak it with you.  I am trying to spend some time now playing games and reading books in Spanish with my kids which keeps their interest and it doesn't feel like extra work for them (My oldest son is now 10 and he actually remembers a lot of words), hopefully this will begin to mend my dumb mistake. 
Good luck!

I live in your city - the commune might have some lessons for you, even better choices for females. They are slow paced and catered to new arrivals pending their approval for settlement ( asylum seekers for example ), new arrivals such as a foreign spouse and so on. These are low cost and not more than once / 4 hours a week. More information from your Stadt Verwaltung, Florhofstr. 6   
In CH, normally one adapts to the way things are, and not the other way around. Private lessons IMO are the best options for you. There are plenty of DE teachers who can be flexible enough to meet your needs. If you need a certificate of proficiency ( A1, A2, B1 etc. ), you might have to sign up at the test center and / or school, nearest being in Zurich city.

When Friedrich DÃ¤niker of the DÃ¤niker English Bookshop died in 1989 at only 70 years, his shop was sold to Orell FÃ¼ssli, who integrated it into their mainshop, but in a rather bad way. Unacceptably bad, a real shame. When Mr Staeheli, a great chap actually, died 10 years later, his shop also was taken over by Orell FÃ¼ssli, and I feared the worst. But Orell FÃ¼ssli in the meantime had come under the influence of a family of real professionals from MÃ¼nchen, and so, what now is the "English Bookshop" at Rennweg was continued as was the Interlingua. The Interlingua amazingly retained the Staeheli name to some extent, which is nice. I think that now, both great old gentlemen would be happy to see what has come out of their two shops     
The start of the Staeheli English bookshop had a cultural-political background. Up to WW-II, lots of German language books were simultaneously printed  in Leipzig, Wien + ZÃ¼rich, as Leipzig was the Capital of German bookprinting. In the first few years of Nazi rule, it was still possible to print good books in Germany, amazingly as it looks. BUT after about 1936, all changed, and books from Leipzig were filled with Nazi ideology. So, as a result of that, Mr Staeheli and his partner decided to go into English language books.

post:
I'm also Irish and am currently trying to get into university in Switzerland in the city of Fribourg.   
I am not 100% sure if this is the same for all universities but the few that I have checked require the following for entry (this includes normal universities and the engineering schools): 
1) 6 leaving certificate subjects. 
2) Minimum of 3 at higher level with a C or higher in each. 
3) Minimum of 3 at ordinary level with a C or higher in each. 
4) Of the 3 higher level subjects one must be in a natural science or maths. 
5) There is generally a language exam required for entry. Each universities / engineering school's language level required differs.   
If you decide to come to switzerland to study it would of course be best to find out first hand from the university what is required.   
I have lived in Fribourg for the last year learning french for entry to the university here (high langauge level required for Fribourg, b2+ in german or french in reference to CELP). Fribourg is very much a student town, similar to galway I would say.   
I can give you a rundown of what kind of prices you'd be facing if you like (of course those would be figures for fribourg).

Feel free to sign up   
If you have a gmail, yahoo mail or other OpenID account, you can sign in with that.

post:
when I first came I chose private lessons in the place closest to my work.  It cost 110 CHF per hour which I find a huge amount of money but I figured it would be worth it.  When I arrived the informed me that the sell these lessons in blocks of 10 - which meant that I owed them 1100 CHF, all I had done was sent an email!   
I didn't care for the teaching style or the materials so I didn't renew after this initial welcome to Switzerland experience.  I have since done a one year course of 2 hours per week and a LOT of my own work, I am now able to communicate quite well, here are the resources I have used, some are free some are low cost   
All the best!       Here is the translation dictionary that I use, you can get a toolbar in your browser and when you highlight a word you click a link to go straight to the translation, make a user account and you can save words to your vocabulary list   www.dict.cc     If you need to know how to conjugate a verb then go to the next link   http://www.verbix.com/languages/german.shtml   Type in the infinitive and your off     http://www.canoo.net/   Very good resource - does too many things for me to explain     Podcasts   www.slowgerman.com   www.geo.de  (seacrch for podcasts)     They are free - the first one is good for beginners.     Reading   www.spiegel.de   A bit advanced but easier than speigel magazine which I also recommend when you progress   www.geo.de   Also not really ideal for beginners - but the stuff they write about is really interesting so keep it for when you progress     www.bkyi.com   Flashcard software - you can get free stuff which is good for beginners or buy it if you want to make your own, I make my own and find it really helpful     I can't remember the text to speech software that I use at the moment, I have it at home.  It isn't free but for the package and two native German voices I paid about CFH 100 - well worth it for what I have been able to do.  You can make mp3s and have them playing on your ipod while you work.  This takes care of all memory work which doesn't have any logic.       I really recommend this   http://www.amazon.co.uk/Frequency-Di...2307674&sr=8-1   It is not really cheap but again well worth it - instead of learning random stuff you can learn the words that are used the most.

Being in the French speaking part of CH - your closest CELTA centre is in Geneva (The Bell School) see link above.   
At this moment in time you can only do the CELTA there, and in Zurich (FT)Full time and in Baden (The language Centre) part time   
As from next year you'll be able to also do the CELTA in St Gallen (part time with Cambridge ESOL) and in Basel Full-time (based at academia school)   
I was a tutor on a CELTA course in York UK.                
1) Fees for the intensive course in the UK are much lower than here in CH    
1095 pounds in the UK - between 3,700 - 4,000+CHF in Switzerland   
(this means if you know someone you can stay with in the UK, it can actually turn out cheaper to do it there)   
2) The CELTA course and your experience on it very much depends on the type of tutors you have.    
3) If you opt to do the intensive don't even consider commuting anymore than 40 mins   it is very intensive to say the least.   
4) The CELTA certainly will help in getting you through the door and into jobs, but the certificate is done in 4 weeks - it provides you with a foundation or a basis to work from. In other words teachers post CELTA normally still need plenty of professional development and training.   
5) Based on the above point - once you have the CELTA it isn't ideal to just then go off and teach in isolation - good schools will offer teachers   internal development opportunities in the form of workshops and teachers meetings and the possibility of a mentor system. These are very valuable. Good schools will also offer to pay for 1 or 2 newer teachers to attend national ETAS conferences as part of that development.     
Hope that helps somewhat 
Steph

the above posts are correct. In German we say "sich von jemandem die Show stehlen" as infinitive, so you coul say e.g.: "er" hat "mir" die Show gestohlen or "er" hat "ihr" die Show gestohlen.

When I first came here I used a company called  . They give lessons to adults and children (ages 6 - 12) via Skype. For some of the course options you have to purchase books, and some have a requirement for homework which you then e-mail to your tutor.    
I found them very flexible, and supportive. I was hospitalised and the owner and my tutor sent me a get well card, and when I came out of hospital they arranged for me to switch to a different lesson model that meant less pressure - and they gave me a good deal on the switch.    
I don't know of anyone who has used the children's course, but if it's anything like the adult lessons it will be good, and the advantage is it's in the comfort of your own home.

Angst and gemÃ¼tlich have now found their way into the English Dictionary for the same reason. Cosy, the 'nearest thing' to gemÃ¼tlich is, by implication, 'small gemÃ¼tlich' and somehow sounds stupid for a bigger group or bigger room.

There are two different things:   
- There is a determinant/article in front, in your sentence: zwei.  
- The questions is: Does it have the needed ending matching Gender/case? 
- When not (here because it is a number where one can not add an ending), then the normal ending goes over to the adjective if there is one. - If several adjectives, they all take the same ending, for order and clarity's sake.  
- If yes, the normal ending is on the determainant/article (eine, dem, jener, dieses...) then the adjective take a "fill-in" ending just to fill in the blanc. 
- There are three cases where ein does not take an ending even though it logically should (Masculin Nominative, Neuter Nominative, Neuter Accusative). The normal ending jumps over to the adjective if there is one.   
Therefore:     
D er  rot e  Hut steht mir gut 
Ein rot er  Hut wÃ¼rde dir gut stehen 
Drei klein e  Kinder haben sich im Supermarkt verlaufen 
Mit mein em  neu en  Nachbarn verstehe ich mich gut.

How about us getting back on topic. Has anyone been in this situation? What did you do? 
My first thought was, if you don't 'have' to use the language in everyday life, go for a trip, even a short one, to the country or area of the language that you are learning and try out the bit you already have. Sometimes it is depressing, but sometimes, when you understand just few words, you are very motivated to have another shot.  
Sometimes taking a short break isn't a bad thing. You don't forget all you have learned by any means, and listening to an early lesson, or reading one of the first chapters again, can be quite fun.

post:
Go figure, I came here to learn German. I arrived here 3 months and 2 weeks ago and I started my German classes after 2 weeks of my arrival.  
I have been wanting to learn German since I was in Gymnasium but most of the schools in my country offer English, French, Latin, some even Russian, German-not so many schools, unless you go to a School or High School that have German classes or everything is in German. I learned English, French and bit Latin.  
Anyway, none of my friends speak German so I was watching TV programmes in German which I liked and I was keep saying that  I want to learn German, it sounds so nice, I like the writting  bla bla. 
So I said ''Ok, I really want to learn German and I have to do something about it''. So I came here. Before coming here I was saying ''Oh I will learn it quite fast, I understand a bit, I know the basic words'' so I was enthusiastic and open to everything that my German course and teacher would offer me. Of course I know and I have been told by so many people in my country and even here that German is not an easy language and why do I really want to learn it? Well, I just want to. 
Now, after 3 months, what do I know?- waaaay too less things than I expected!! I think I expected too much from my self!! I can not believe that after 3 months of German classes I am cr@p. I understand, I read quite well, I write well but my speaking sucks. I have no words, I don't know how to make a right sentence and I am confused. 
I even have some people in my class that have been living here for 4yrs or 6 yrs and they don't speak German! I didn't ask them but the reasons in my opinion are: they have a job that doesn't require German, their friends and families don't speak German and they preffer to speak their native language, when they go shopping they just pick things from the shelf or search for them untill they find it, instead of asking for help, and they just pay on the way out, if they need help somewhere they will just use their English. 
In my case I want to apply for UZH but apparently they only have  1 German test a year, in January 2011, and I have to get to a B2 level by then, for me it is impossible! I am going to an A1 level eventhough all the tests I am taking (online) say I am an A2 towards B1 level (maybe they are wrong) but I am so dissapointed because I can't apply next year and I will lose a year just like that, that I don't even have the drive to learn German anymore, I feel I came here for nothing and it will take me so much time to learn it that I will get bored of it. In fact I am bored on my German class because everybody is slow and I don't like being slow, I want to progress. I think I will change the class/level or take a break.

post:
The International English route really is the way to go for anyone typing more than three umlauts/accents in a message. The cut/paste from the Character map can truly get tedious.   
You can easily *push in the clutch* for the International English for the duration and then then shift back. As soon as you define multiple input languages, you can get a little menu added to the task bar with a keyboard button from which you can switch back and forth. (Be careful: I often accidentally stumble upon the keyboard shortcuts (which I've since disabled) to switch between input locales).   
These characters are called "diacriticals" - consisting of the accent character and then the accented character (e.g.: " and then a  to form Ã¤). If you ARE in international English and you want one of the characters, if you just press ", you'll see nothing. I often use " followed by a space. Once the diacritical isn't "satisfied" (i.e., after " you enter something for which there's no umlaut), you get the " and then the character. " and then z gives you "z. " and then space gives you only the " (the same holds true for the others, ", ', etc.). ' and e gives you Ã©. Oddly, ' and c gives you Ã§.

It's all about cases.   
Q: Wie geht es Ihnen? A: Gut. Und Ihnen?  "Ihnen" refers to the indirect object of the verb "gehen". So the dative case required. (  geht es gut?)   
Q: Was haben Sie gestern gemacht? A: Ich habe gearbeitet. Und Sie?  "Sie" refers to the subject of the verb "machen". So the the nominative case is required. (  hat etwas gemacht?)

First of all, Ziger, you did not understand that danish is not even my mother tongue.  
Secondly, intelligibility in scandinavia is defined as intelligibility between speakers of different languages. 
Third point, intelligibility between English speakers is a question of intelligibility between speakers of the same language.   
So, one more time more simple words: 
It is easy to understand each other NO/DK with a little willingness although the differences are defining them as different languages,  
THUS, 
understanding other English speakers should not be more difficult that scandinavians among themselves do.   
But do NOT put words into my mouth, what you infer about yourself from my message are your imagination only, not my words.

Interesting is relative - depends what you like...   
German TV shows: 
- Schlag den Raab - it's a show where some candiates compete against a German TV moderator in different kinds of sports 
- TV Total - kind of like a late night comedy show with the same guy as in the above Stefan Raab 
- Wetten dass...? - live bets on TV with celebrities 
- Wer wird Millionaer? - German version of who wants to be a millionaire - might actually be good for learning german vocab 
- Deutschland sucht den Superstar - German version of American Idol or Pop Idol   
TV series: 
- Tatort - crime series 
- Galileo - more like a knowledge/documentary series 
- Komissar Rex - not sure if that one actually still runs but its also a crime series - main character is a German shepherd 
- Der Alte - crime series 
- Ein Fall fuer 2 - also crime series     
Im not a soap fan and I cannot stand Desperate Housewives, Lost, all these soppy hospital series etc. I have a short attention span when it comes to those and I cannot follow every day whilenothing ever happens and then the season ends. If you want cheesy German soaps though, try Lindenstrasse, Marienhof, Unter Uns, Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten, Verbotene Liebe.   
I assume you can get these online somewhere. ARD and ZDF (German public TV stations have shows online, look for the Mediathek on their websites   and   )

I am not sure what you expect from your French speaking friends, if it is to learn the lingo - think about what benefit they would have form hanging out with you...It sounds funny, I know, but if people speak no language or a very little, it gets boring to constantly correct. If you speak well, then of course you will find friends in no time (yes, it is efficient), especially given your outgoing personality, etc. But if your level is low, take a class and maximize your exposure (extra conv classes, language exchanges, etc.) Volunteering is really good, people are patient, will help you out. But you might want to rethink your apparel maybe, image, etc. - some of the religious volunteering organizations might object   and also the fact that culturally, people here are a lot more...low key, down playing themselves, not as suggestive, etc. and from your posts, it seems you are one of a big kinky party animal. So, if you want friends, you will most probably click with similar mindsets, students, young organisations (there is something called Org for free time, I know they have bunch of courses, afternoon activities, Geneva is really good with this, google it). Uni is a great source for activities, as well. In fact, I am heading today to a Ge mycological society, since I love picking mushrooms and it is too cool to miss. Might not be your cup of tea, but the French I am learning - fab, much better than courses! Just look around, go to theater groups, some activity driven bunch of peeps, so you don't just party. Good luck and up and at it (books ain't that bad, afterall, I promise...)

post:
You'll be just fine.  I live a couple of miles up the road from EPFL and belong to their library (open to all Swiss residents, not just students).  A very large proportion of the books are in English, all the library staff speak terrific English - there will be plenty of people for you to talk to, and who will happily give you a hand with translating an electric bill and whatnot.   
In the wider area, you could very easily 'survive' with just English, but will of course have a better and more enriching experience if you move into French-speaking circles.  Any attempt at all with the language, even if the conversation then switches to English, is met with encouragement and pleasure as so many people here just stay in their English comfort zone and expect the shop staff, mechanics, etc to make all the concessions.   
Lots of info on here already about good ways to learn languages - scan the threads.   
Good luck for your move.   
kodokan

post:
Your English has a lot of grammar errors and oddities.  For the most part your sentences are understandable but take some work to get through.  For example, I have noticed that saying "Ein dunkles Weizen, bitte" in a pub works far better than "Ein dunkel Weizen, bitte".  The former is actually understood faster and easier even though both should be obvious.   
I will give you a few points to remember, but really an instructor should be explaining this to you in person:   
In English it extremely rare and somewhat poetic to have an object be "he" or "she".   
Next, you normally don't want a comma before that. Especially when it introduce a clause serving as an object.  "I see that you are right." is right, "I see, that you are right." is wrong.    
"like for example" is extremely casual, you would in any serious writing replace it with something else, such as "such as".   
P.S. I think that billhardie made some changes which are themselves mistakes. e.g. reknown is not a word in English and "such as 'thanks giving' for example" is redundant in a bad way.

Not really.  If I knew a bit of Welsh or a bit of Rumantsch, yes, I would probably go out of my way to find practice opportunities.  I would chat indefatigably about yesterday's weather and My Hometown and the new red shoes of the baker's wife's cousin's daughter and be thrilled just to be   the language no matter how banal the topic.     
Living in Zurich, though, I get enough German immersion just going about my daily life that I don't feel the need to seek it out specially.  As it is, I socialize pretty indiscriminately: I go out with whoever I feel like  going out with, and speak whichever language that calls for as well as I  can, and if I can't speak it I nod and smile.  I don't exclaim over new  idioms, take notes or ask people to repeat themselves because (a) I  have a special horror of being a nuisance, and (b) it is too much like  work.  Treating your whole social life as a language lab may be a worthy idea  but it is   tedious.

post:
When talking to Germans, even "real" Swiss tend to translate - Handy - because they know Natel is widely unknown in Germany.  
When speaking to foreigners in German, some Swiss will keep the perfectly Schriftdeutsch Natel, others will change it into the more German Hochdeutsch Handy. Some Swiss may think (wrongly) that Natel is dialectal and will be hypercorrect and use the German word that they think is more Hochdeutsch.   
In short: you will hear both, but mind the reasonning behind the word change. And Natel is perfectly correct Swiss Hochdeutsch, written and spoken.

Yes, it does, especially when speaking.   
When writing, the mistakes appear quite obviously, because it is very rare that a word properly spelled can have either a masculine or feminine meanings .   
When speaking, the gender-mistakes can be of little importance quite often, but it can also be really confusing with a bit bad luck, or too much confidence/persistence in the "wrong" gender.   
Some words, by sound, have different meanings when they are used with a masculine or feminine article. Here are some examples that pop to my mind :   
 - la fÃªte (the party), le faÃ®te (the top) or le fait (the fact).   ( ) /=    
 - un fil (a thread, or a phone call), une file (a queue).    
 - un noeud (a knot), une (one, a she-thing).  .   
 - un pÃ¨re (the father) une paire (a pair).    
 - la vie, le vit... J'aime la vie, j'aime le vit...   
It can also be confusing, and turn a proper sentence in a mess (so imagine the mess it can become if there is some additional mistakes...) For example : 
 - [correct]   ( ) 
 - [not correct]   ( , with a lacking article for  , and a foreigner-like pronunciation for  )   
The gender gets also declined, so the mistake can become more subtle : 
- [correct]  (de le => du ) 
 - [not correct]  de la pain = deux lapins, so: )   
If you use a pronoun (il/elle) for naming wrongly a feminine/masculine thing, then it become even more confusing.   instead of  .   
I guess it requires some serious efforts to remember the masculine/feminine of things, but it's worth it. People having French as their mother tongue would almost never mingle the masculine and feminine of things, so it's quite unexpected for them when foreigners make such mistakes, especially when the mistakes are amplified by a logically-correct declinations of adjectives and pronouns; for example:  , the mistake can be understood only when the last word is pronounced, and before that,  and   had quite rule out the eventuality that the feminine word   would be finally pronounced, let's say that some French-speaking would think the last pronounced is more likely tableau (masculine) than table.   
/Paul

Note that you can be asked to sign a VerzichtserklÃ¤rung for any situation where you might have otherwise a claim to something. 
Effectively it is simply a document that waives your rights to something and to be permitted must explain the extent of what you are giving up. 
Examples include: 
for bequests which might also be of negative value,  
for freeing the organiser of an event against subsequent claims maybe when a band plays poorly or it rains so you can't pitch a tent etc 
for freeing against claims of value something for which you have not paid classically here are free air tickets through collecting miles 
For transferring a mobile number to another company (the telephone company needs to declare their willingness to give up a number out of their block so the number can be used by the new provider)   
And so it goes on.

The original Reithalle were used to exercise horses in, during the cold winters. They are built like very large barns with high roofs. Recently a new one was built at the national horse center near Avenches.

I studied with LSI some years back.  Firstly, go direct and not through Cactus.  If I recall, my first contact with them was via Cactus, which then bound me into the deals Cactus offer, which were not as good or flexible as going direct.   
I found LSI a mixed bag - one tutor I had was great for me (very structured, grammatical, logical rule based approach to the language), but had a girl in our course near to tears on numerous occasions as he could not appreciate that style wasn't working well for her.   
In other respects I found it frustrating - they were disorganised, sometimes having no desks available for the class.  The afternoon discussion classes were pretty random, and seemed to suit the interests of the tutor better than the student - one guy took us to visits to the Landesmuseum and medical museum, sometimes we watched films (albeit in German, but on a dodgy little TV with crappy speakers).  Found all that pretty unsatisfactory.

Hi Lob, I don't actually agree on that one. This happened to me my first month or so, but as I improved my pronunciation and fluency it stopped happening. In fact the opposite happened - many Swiss would then be embarassed to speak English around me, as if I would judge them. I found this most curious. Nowadays I only get the switch to english thing once in a while, usually from someone who is overjoyed at the chance to practice.   
One thing to bear in mind that many expats, even though they work really hard on their german seem to do very little work on their pronunciation. The English seem to have a habit of putting umlauts on all their vowel sounds and refusing to do the deeper sounds such as u and o. Most insist on pronouncing Zug as "Zoooog" (as if it were spelt sÃ¼Ã¼g in German). Many Americans seem totally unaware of the rolling "R" in German, flattening it and dragging it into a nasal sound which is like fingernails on a blackboard to a native speaker. These dead giveaways simply trigger a response in a native that "this person is very uncomfortable with German" and the response would come in English simply out of politeness.   
To think about it another way - imagine you are in the UK and someone comes up to you and says "vitch vay to bahnhof". You'd hear the heavy accent and probably answer in German. But if you just heard a light German accent, you'd most likely answer in English.

OK, I went to the RAV interview today.  They told me I need to be in CH at least 3 months, submit 5 to 8 job applications a month, send them proof that I was denied. After the 3 months, they will pay for the German Language class. In the same school I'm in.   
They also told me, that they have 2,000 people registered jobless ( don't know if in that office or the Canton) and they only find around 50 jobs a month for them, and usually they are low skilled jobs. So I was better off, getting a headhunter or looking on my own than using their services.   
They told me where to get my Bachelor's diploma certified, also to get my social security card (AHV) and some other tips. So I guess it was worth it.    
Good Luck All!

No guarantees on scientific accuracy, but should help you understand the article:     Probenvorbereitung  - specimen preparation
Einwaage - initial weight   Stamm - stem (as in stem cell), could also be strain (bacteria) - hard to know without context   Bei - at, by, during, etc (a proposition - again, don't know without context)   Solleinwaage - expected initial weight   Steigung -- increase/incline (sounds like looking at changes in weight, so would go with increase, but could also be used to indicate slope/incline   Achsenabschnitt - intercept -- assume now that above is slope   Muster - sample/specimen   Soll-einwaage - see above (expected initial weight)   Berechne - calculate   Gehalt - normally salary, but in your context probably more likely that it is concentration or level   Unkorrigiert - uncorrected   Mittlewert - average, mean or midpoint (Mittel, not mittle)   Zu rapportierender gehalt - concentration to be reported   Unter - below   Berucksichtigung - consideration (assume unter Bereuchsichtigung together - under consideration of ...)   Wiederfindung - recovery/retrieval   Proben-auswertung - sample analysis     Hope this helps!

Exactly. First I was going to suggest a translator. A text like this (especially towards the end) can easily be misinterpreted.   
Asking readers to give you a reference as to the level of your writing, well, that's something more conceivable.   
It depends, of course, what you want to use the language for. I guess in some contexts, it could be sufficient, while in others not.   
As a teacher, I'd just suggest that you do other things than translate (provided that the text is your work). Sometimes one's mother tongue can negatively influence the output, given the differences between the two languages. Try forgetting about the original language and use the (little or more) English you have. I know its more and more difficult to do as we get older, but it improves our skills a lot if we don't rely on our mother tongue but use the rules and words we know in the other language. And reading similar texts than the one you're trying to write will give you an idea of the phrases you might use

Personally, I like Galileo, on Pro7. It's a science-oriented educational little show, often doing some pretty entertaining, although maybe a little silly, experiments (e.g. which chewing gums resist better to YEARS of mechanical chewing  ).  
Since it has a news-like structure, it's pretty easy not to lose concentration.   
Also for a ground level, I suggest cartoons  . The ones which are meant to preschoolers (say Mickey Mouse Wunderhaus, Winnie the Pooh, Dora, Caillou) guarantee a pretty high rate of understanding since the concepts and words are...well...suitable for toddlers.

post:
Rules and signs mean nothign to some people. One Hauswart I know well (he and his wife look after a group of small buildings) told me that the state some people leave the laundry room in can be awful.    
What I find amazing is that in flats with specific wash days and sign up sheets, you almost always know who the culprit is. The best thing is to tell the Hauswart and let them confront the culprit. Unfortunately, no amount of signage or rules is going to change the way some people behave.    
It's a real pain when you have to clean up after someone before you can begin washing.   
It's no wonder everyone wants their own washer/dryer. This is becoming more and more popular now and some people are willing to pay that little bit extra for this.    
Other than flats built to be sold, renovated apartments in unusual buildings (without cellars) tend to have their own laundry, as do houses. The advantage of the shared laundry is you have more drying space often with a wall dryer.

Since we're sharing... posted this one before, but quite a while ago so here it is for the newbies:       
It's the US Foreign Service course, used to to train diplomats before shipping them out overseas.  Don't be fooled by the course being called 'Basic' - it goes from beginner up to a very solid B1, almost B2 level (good enough for free-flowing conversation and almost any situation you'll find yourself in).   
Choose a course (I'd recommend Basic, then after a few months try the Phonology to tidy up pronunciation of those tricky vowels), open up the workbook, then play the associated 'tape'.   
(Edit: Just been reading the forums on the FSI site, and apparently for total beginners it's best to start with the Phonology THEN move to the Basic; if you already have rusty school French you could do it the other way round, which is what I did.)   
It's an old course, from around the 1960s or 70s I think, so don't expect whizzy graphics or fun.  It's traditional learning, with lots of repetition and lots of verb drills.  But it's very, very effective, very comprehensive and totally free!   
kodokan   
PS: There are also lots of other languages on the FSI course, including German and Italian

post:
And to really speed up the process, read out loud.  Remember how you learned to chant times tables as a kid, so that merely by saying '5 nines are...' the answer would pop into your head to finish the pattern?  It's just like that - after a while, sentences will just 'sound' right, the way they do in your native language.   
Pronunciation doesn't matter for this, so don't worry overmuch about it.  And make it easy on yourself - stick things up around the house, so you can read out loud little and often.  Our entire downstairs bathroom is wallpapered with articles and kids' comics, and I regularly change what's on the kitchen cupboard above where the kettle boils.   
kodokan   
PS: Just re-reading, and perhaps reading out loud was what MathsNut meant all along.  Never mind, I've typed it all out now, and the wall/cupboard bit's useful.

For dictionaries, I used the Oxford Multi-Language Pack Pro, which I use frequently.  For verb conjugation, the Ultralingua dictionary proves useful.

post:
hello   
i've been a student at both Goethe and GLS in Berlin. Goethe is very expensive relative to the other schools in Berlin, but the teachers are very good and I would rate the course highly.   
Prior to Goethe I was at GLS   which is a lot cheaper and the teachers I had were also pretty good. If i was going back I would probably just go to GLS because its cheaper and at my beginner level its all pretty much the same. You can start any monday from one week up. This is good but also a downside if you're there a little longer as your classmates always change.   
Another option is the volkshochschule, there are branches all around Berlin at its very cheap but i hear the teaching quality can vary. This is the one nearest to me when I was there      
if you're a german citizen there is also some deal where the government will subsidise 600 hours of german language courses at VHS, but unfortunately I didn't hear about it till I was about to leave. I can dig up some details if thats the case for you.
Thansk Pacman, you de man

I think it would depend upon your usage needs...?   
If you are looking to work in some corporate office, it is likely that your needs will be for "High" German and English (assuming one is hired from the standpoint that they ALREADY speak English) and then learn Swiss German for day-to-day dealings outside of work.   
ON the other hand - 
If one is working in a "front line" position, say a hotel desk clerk, a store sales associate, a restaurant server... I think learning Swiss German first is more valuable as spoken communication then takes precedence over written.

I am a French teacher (for primary school kids that is) and I always find that listening to radio programmes or buying books on cd's can help.    
If you are a beginner then try to dive into the language as well as you can, make sure you surround yourself by it, giving your brain the message: This is important.    
Thinking.... I will go and check whether they have those audios in French too....

Hurray...  This may really help you. If it is anythign similar to the one I did in Albanian it is well worth it.    
Other than that playgrounds are great places to learn a language in too. Find French speaking moms (if you have any kids, that is) and off you go.... engage in a conversation...

post: Try the Migros language courses

hi there   
i'm also attending this course now, it's my second one. i'm at b2 level now.

To start at the end, NO. Switzerland should not separate from German. The dialects spoken in the Alsace, in southern Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg up to Stuttgart, in southwestern Bavaria and in Vorarlberg and Tirol are almost or really the same as the Swiss-German ones. "Native German speakers" ?  Depends on where they are from. People from South Germany and Western Austria understand most Swiss German dialects.    
Low German is a term which refers to the "Lowlands" of NorthWest Germany, with one of its forms being Platt-Deutsch which sounds similar to Dutch (and even English) but by structure and grammar is closer to Standard German than the South German, Swiss German, West Austrian dialects.    
You remind me of a visit to Leipzig and Halle, where I told a local from Halle that Switzerland was positive about German reunification, but at the other hand could have lived with two, three, four or five Germanies, and also for instance with the Kingdom of Bavaria (having Bavarian as national language). It then was HIS point to be VERY positive about the idea

post:
i used to keep a notebook (eventually i migrated to excel), in which i maintained a list of words i learnt. but there were too many to note, so i kept only those i thought were useful/interesting. at the beginning, i would conscientiously go back to review the words, but i never recorded the context in which the word was used, which presented various challenges. knowing what a word meant, did not necessarily mean i knew how to   it. nothing stuck, eventually i gave up. its akin to the german theory of "logical atomism."   
then i started doing newspaper cuttings, looked up the words and wrote them on some space on the article (printing off the internet gives you more space). this way, i have a finite number of new words to learn, an article that put meanings in context and sentences that demonstrated its use. it's a mini "logical holism" that strings everything together nicely. i file them away for future references, as i know certain words are often used in certain topics.   
when learning new words, i accept that i will forget a good portion of what i come across, maybe 50%. so i just try to do as many cuttings as i can

Can anyone recommend a German/Swiss interpreter in Zurich who may be able to assist in attending apartment viewings for those landlords that do not speak english. I may only rely only on this should I actually find something I like however cash or other tangible goods can be negotiated for services rendered.

To save my pedantry hijacking a recent thread I thought I'd point the difference out here. It may help some people who are in need of one or the other, and could help avoid an embarrassing situation where wrong person has been employed   
A   typically translates the written word from one language to another - books, documents - anything that is written. From my knowledge most translators translate in one direction only, normally from foreign language into mother tongue. Of course there are exceptions to this and it is possible to find translators who can work in both directions equally ably.   
An   translates the spoken word immediately, and does so with both languages - typically employed for interviews, discussions, speeches etc.   
Of course the crossover between the two types is large and there are people who work as both translator and interpreter.   
HTH

I learnt both French and German for a few years, although I definitely focused on the latter, spending maybe 3 times as much time on it than French.   
I'd say go for it, given you have a few years to play with and that you're keen. Given you have a little background in French, maybe start just with that, develop some good learning habits, try it out in real life if you can, then start German.   
The languages are very different and you won't confuse them. You should find French easier though, especially to read, with your background in English.
